product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: It goes on completely citrus cleaner, but dries down to a very intimant honey sweetness quick enough to be worth it. Not a perfect honey perfume, but a pleasant entry to that category which doesn’t mix in too many other scents. Now if only Lush would release a Sticky Date perfume.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: Sweet honey that has a beautiful soft dry down. Perfect.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: I'm not much of a gourmand girlie, so I'm more than content with my wee 10ml via the Kitchen box, but my goodness do I love the HIWTK scent family! Brings to mind orange chocolate, honeycomb and gooey caramel all at once. Makes me feel like I'm being hugged by the person I love most. Super sweet, decedent, and above all, comforting -- but HEAVY emphasis on that 'super sweet' part. As much as I love HIWTK, in perfume format it's a bit too much for me a lot of the time (it released about 2 years ago according to the label, and I've only used about 3ml so far!), so I gravitate towards the handful of other gourmands I own a lot of the time. (FWIW, that would mainly be Replica Matcha Meditation & Kilian Angels' Share.) I'm still glad to own this vial for the handful of times I'm in the mood to rock it, but admittedly I prefer it a lot more in bath bomb, shower gel and soap format.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: Why oh why don't they make this scent perfume anymore and why is it always stuck in the U.K. and never in thr states , I just received a lush kitchen version and it it's awesome and honeyed unlike the body spray which is enjoyable , and both have different facets why they should both be here .

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
Initially candy caramel but dries down to vanilla yogurt quite quickly.
Not what I had expected - wanted a thick, rich caramel!

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
This is such a comforting, feel good fragrance. Imagine a creamy toffee, milk and honey, french nougat and orange marmalade. This is probably what Paddington Bear would smell like if you gave him a snuggle!

I own the body spray version of this fragrance, and longevity is really really good.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: This review is for the 2018 body spray. It opens with almost a yogurt tang. That tangy scent dries down quite quickly and morphs into a white floral/honey/toffee scent. It eventually settles into a lovely honey/toffee/white chocolate with only a hint of the white floral. I do not detect any citrus in this version. Not huge sillage or lasting power.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: I expected a perfume replica of the soap (cf. Devil's Nightcap) but to my surprise it's actually not. There's a bit of sour, white wine tinge. I'd liken this perfume to vanilla yogurt.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
Wow! It smells just like the notes listed! If you love sweet gourmands then one not to miss. Quite an intense opening. Too sweet for me. Loads of toffee! I was hoping the citrus might be more dominant but nope.
Moderate sillage and longevity

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
I'm reviewing the 2015 Lush Kitchen formula.
This is absolutely divine! This smells like toffee/caramel and honeycomb with a light soapy feel which is very true to the original scent in the LUSH soap. There is also a slightly white chocolately vibe which reminds me of the best hot chocolate money can buy. Or a bar of "crunchy" chocolate which they sell here in the UK (honeycomb covered in chocolate). It is very wearable, however, and not overpowering. I usually would not wear gourmands this thick in the summer heat, but this is light enough that it works in all weathers. Very clean smelling, despite the foody notes, and perfect those looking for something sweet and yummy without being too much.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: This perfume is certainly something else. With a very prominent Play Doh note, crayon waxy toffee, very sweet and unmistakable. The honey is sweet, a little pee-y and the orange is mostly sweet and just a little zesty, bringing out the higher pitch in this caramel. Don't say I didn't warn you. The liquid, long discontinued, smells the same and is as strong as the solid currently for sale in Japan. The perfume is exactly the same as the soap, except the perfume is ten times more potent. Wear in minute amounts and this can be a real beauty.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: They have discontinued the parfum, but you can still find the scent in soap and in the solid shampoo bar. I love the honey with a hint of carmel/toffee scent. It is sweet but not cloying and doesn't make me hungry. My favorite Lush scent.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
I LOVE "It's Raining Men" shower gel from Lush. It does fabulous things for my hair and smells delicious. I love the "Gold Fun" bath playdough, the "Honey I Washed The Kids" soap (minus the wax on the top), and even the "Honey Bee" bath bomb even though it leaves clay in my tub. So naturally I had to hunt down the perfume to complete the scent circle. I always use their solids when first trying out a scent if I can, since my allergies can be iffy-wiffy. Omg, this smells so amazing and just like the bath products!

Buttery goodness with just enough citrus to balance out the sweetness, and just enough floral to make the honey smell realistic and not like cheap vanilla.


Edit: So the solid of this definitely leans more toward a butterscotch scent, whereas the spray version has a slightly more floral feel going. Both are awesome, though.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
For anyone wondering, the Lush shops in Japan still carry this as a solid perfume: other than the UK, Japan has the most Lush shops in the world! If anyone's looking for this discontinued perfume, you may want to get one shipped in from there. (Japan Lush also carries The Olive Branch solid perfume)

Delicious honey/caramel smell.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: Simple 3 note wonder. First scent is largely of caramel, rich and thick but not too syrupy or burnt. It is seamlessly layered with bee's wax and honey, which evens out the smell of the caramel and gives it a 'thick' smell. Lastly, is a bit of orange which keeps the whole thing from smelling too sweet and gives it a slight fruit identity. It smells kind of soapy too, like the wax of glycerin soap. Sort of like clean skin musk. I think this helps create the illusion that the scent was transferred onto your skin by soap rather than perfume.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: They should make this perfume into food so I can eat it. Smells delicious, definitely gourmand but clean as well with a soapy finish which makes it very wearable. I wore this at Christmas all the time as it seemed perfect for the season.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: I had a solid version of this perfume and enjoyed it. Cozy and playful, clean and warm, with a touch of honey sweetness. The name of this perfume helps to bring these diverse sniff-impressions together :)

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: The soap is great, but the perfume (might have been the bottles I got--I got two different ones, one from each release, though) was kinda...well, it smelled mostly like alcohol and something bitter from the bottle. On the skin, it mellowed out to something closer to the soap, but usually still a little too bitter/waxy for me.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: It smells like the soap, but not as subtle. It was a special edition. I can see why they didn't put it in their permanent line. Something was just off..

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
Unfortunately discontinued.
I know they still sell it as soap, but I recently tried Flying Fox and actually liked it better. Probably because I love jasmine. I'm hoping they'll eventually produce Flying Fox as a fragrance.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: I keep buying the soap , but can't find the perfume in my country ( ITALY)

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
When it comes to gourmands, I am much more enthusiastic about wearing something that smells like honey rather than cotton candy. I've been searching for a realistic honey scent for quite some time. I did enjoy Serge Lutens Miel de Bois, but it wasn't what I wanted. Since finding Honey I Washed The Kids, I believe I may have found the closest to what I was looking for.

Honey I Washed The Kids is a fairly linear scent, with syrupy honey, sugary vanilla and gooey caramel. It smells delicious and foody, just like a gourmand should be.

The opening is where the honey note is at its strongest. I was amazed by how realistic it smelt on my skin. It was just like sticking your nose in a jar of honey and inhaling. Although the honey note is dominant throughout this composition, it does tend to lessen in intensity. The heart and drydown introduces the vanilla and caramel which helps in balancing out the fragrance.

As far as I'm aware, Honey I Washed The Kids was a limited edition that has long since been discontinued. The last time I inquired about this fragrance in a Lush store, I was re-directed to a shower gel named It's Raining Men and told that it's the same scent, just re-named.

I was lucky enough to be sent a sample from a kind Lush fragrance collector. Since falling for it, I guess I'll now have to join the ranks of fans waiting for a bottle to appear on Ebay.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: I wanted to love this and I am a honey fan. But the orange and bergamont made this too lemoney for my taste. It dries down and for like an hour, smells divine. It smells like honey, toffee and creamy vanilla. I also didn't care for the solid form which I had to scrape with my fingernail out of the tin. Luckily the Bath and Body Works reformulation of Warm Vanilla Sugar smells like the dry down of this. I highly recommend.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: Does anyone know of a fragrance that truly smells like Honey I Washed The Kids soap and hasn't been discontinued?

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
Sweeeeeeet but dont care coz HIWTK is lovely super YUMMY scent! It's rich caramel toffee!!

If you still cant imagine how is the scent and dont have LUSH shop nearby, u can go supermarket & find Werther's original candy, it is the same!!!

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: Yummy! They captured this scent very nicely. Smells just like HIWTK soap and It's Raining Men shower gel. It is extremely sweet but so yummy. It's a very honey, caramel, and slightly floral scent that just makes you want to eat yourself!! lol

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: Oh how I WISH they still had this available... The one LUSH perfume I cannot find anymore :-(

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: YUMMMMMMMMMM

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
I am a fan of Lush's Honey I Washed the Kids Soap and was excited when the fragrance edition of this scent came out. Unfortunately there's something here that's not quite right with this scent.

On my skin it never settles down to that gorgeous toffee/honey/caramel scent that I've come to love. I believe the bergamot and orange mixture in this is what's making this rather sharp. There's no warmth here, its very much a cold sharp sweet smell that reminds me of white bleached sugar.

However, when my bottle of this leaked onto a scarf I was delighted to find the resulting scent a lot closer to the warm toffee caramel scent I love. I wont be repurchasing this but its a nice thing to have in my collection.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
I really love Lush a lot.They care so much for the Mother Earth,and for the animals. I still have a pinch left of the solid for this lovely vegan scent,but I am running really low. I am sad that mine is almost gone.

I simply cannot afford this spray (I want it though,and I am so happy it is vegan)

I have a GORGEOUS dupe from a sweet online seller. It is a roll-on oil. It smells like sweet orange candy, and toffee. Very softly scented.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
There is something fresh lingering behind the sweetness, something that refreshes you while it lulls you. It's not really citrussy rather what's left after the citrussy has gone. A tingy sharpness that gives this sweet scent its charm.

Whenever I use it, people react. I love it, it lifts my mood.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content: Toffee, salted caramelised oranges and honey. Not enough honey IMHO, there's an almost Greek Honey yoghurt quality to this, not too bad at all, but works better in the Lush soap form.

product_name: Honey I Washed the Kids Lush
review_content:
I used to work in Lush so am very familiar with this smell. It's a one of kind gorgeousness that's hard to describe. The description of Citrus/Gourmand is wrong in my opinion. It's not citrussy.
If you think this blend is going to be overwhelmed by honey then fear not.
It's a very light, almost Tofee-Lite smell which is sooo addictive and comforting. Beautiful beautiful smell. The soap and other products are just as gorgeous. If you've ever had a chocolate bar called "Caramac" then you're onto the right track of what this smells like.

Yeah this is really good. Fizzy sherbet-y aldehyde-citrus opening, savoury musk, spicy rose and oakmoss and a very wearable oud note (I love how oud smells but tend to have to take a very cautious approach because smelling it on myself all day can tip over into headache territory easily). Weird combination of very edible-smelling Lush-y notes and the quite oldschool aldehyde-rose-moss chypre but it definitely works.
I see how this is marketed as a beachy scent but it’s way more versatile than that suggests - the cozy musk and woods means it works well in colder weather and it’s sexy and (weirdly for Lush, elegant) enough to go from day to night too. Has the classic insane lasting power of the Lush body sprays - does dry down to a skin scent after a few hours but if you get this on clothes you will be projecting it for days.
Curious to try layering it with more traditional rose or chypre scents to see what happens - I feel like there’s a rosy-woody-spicy strain in common with Chanel Coco that it could play nicely with but that’s such a beast in its own right that amping it up further could just be antisocial.

I rather naively bought my two young people this for Christmas. Both bottles sat there unused, then one of my young people turned 17 and wanted to wear scents. So they started wearing it, I had never smelled Oud and at first thought it was too strong, then it settled into this lovely warm freshness. So I’ve nabbed the second bottle, keeping it for other sibling and using some occasionally.
Slightly reminiscent of seawater, but not as pungent or fishy. Has a slightly salty, musky quality. Essentially pleasant and neutral smell.

I enjoy this much more than stormy weather. I do get a salty effect. I’m not a fan of oud in general but this is appealing. I wouldn’t mind if my man wore it. Too masculine for me overall, but I really wanted to find a pirate themed scent that I can wear with my pirate costume this Halloween. After some trial and error, I’ve decided that sticky dates and salty layer quite well to achieve a more complex boozy-salty-wood effect that is exactly what I’d had in mind.

This perfume doesn't feel salty as such, but I definitely get what people are saying about hot person armpit. it's that mixed with them wearing a natural solid deodorant bar! I really like this as a trans-masc / butch lesbian (I see some others mentioned this as well). It feels very neutral, a sort of musky bad ass vibe with a soft touch. It's intriguing that the notes coming together, make this smell. I don't really see any of the notes in it at all! I can't quite pin point what I can smell. I do find that bergamot has a body odour vibe, which sort of feels like it's In this scent. This smell is great for feeling like you're not over doing it, but want to smell good. It feels like a personal aroma .

Addictive opening. Sex on the beach with a surfer. Whoever first described it as “hot person armpit” was spot on. I can see why this is popular with butch lesbians.

The dry-down leaves much to be desired. The longevity is fine, but it lingers to leave a powdery, plastic-like scent (almost like a crayon).

The oud is surprisingly not stifling, simply attractive. Definitely try before buying, the notes do not describe the overall effect well enough.

Pairs quite well with the solid perfume Dirty, as it gives it that minty freshness. I would also recommend a fruity or citrus-based shower gel, like Olive Branch.

enticed by the description of this as something very sexy and salty (esp the hot person armpit comparison), i ordered a bottle off of mercari. it opens strong, sort of woody, herby, and astringent. it reminds me of the chinese medicine stores of my youth, and tobacco smoke. it softens after about 20 minutes into something a smidge more powdery and floral, a little muskier too, but sadly with very little salt. perhaps i'm lacking in imagination or sexual experience, but to this bisexual woman, it smells alluring and intimate, but not erotic.

edit: i love this. what was she (me ^) on about. i mean, i think i'm still right about the opening, which i think just sits poorly on my skin but, girl, this is so good. i spray it twice on my throat and once on each wrist and it sits around me in a divine cloud. it is a tinge aftershavey, but not as blue or cold. it does smell salty. it does not smell like sex but it does smell delicious.
This layers excellently with all my rose and white floral perfumes. It's the most elegant of lush's body sprays and oud is gentle not stifling. Don't know if all queer women love it but I do!

All I could say is that this body spray smells like the hairy armpit of an attractive person.
It opens funky in the first minute. A mix of Florida water, rose water, freshly cracked black pepper, powdery incense (not smoky!) and something sour. Like vomit. But like,
༺ 𝓿𝓸𝓶𝓲𝓽 ༻, cursive and all. Man, I don't know, please don't be scared.
Anyway, after that momentary roughness, it's a pretty predictable and smooth ride here on out. The woody powderiness is turned up a notch, very geranium and soap-like. Something in this prevents it from smelling like old-school men's perfume, because that's where I thought this was going. Magic starts to unfold within the 6-7 minute mark. Up close on the skin, it's burning the delicate hairs in my nose. But from a distance, though?
A gentlemanly, polite whiff of this tells you everything you need to know. It's musky. Warm. And just enough of a hint of floral sweetness. It's not fresh-floral by any means. Salty? Eh. Maybe. But If I'm smelling this down the street I'm tearing off your clothes. I don't know what they're putting in this ugly ass bottle but it's beefy. Testosterone pumped. Bite and chew on a bicep kinda vibe. Did I mention it smells like the hairy armpit of an attractive person? Yeah. It does. It's balmy the way deodorant smells like on a CLEAN armpit after a sweaty gym sesh. And it has to be hairy. I've smelt both hairy and hairless attractive people armpit and can safely say it's the former. It's horny, but celibate. Voluntarily. Ya hear that? Your conventionally hot, extroverted, friendly brunette gym crush that knows and talks to everybody in the gym. They do upper body on most days, especially back.
However, if that's not your first impression, I could easily describe this as smelling like a Lush store from afar. It has that quintessential Lush, patchouli smell.
Salty is one of the safest Lush perfumes you can get. If, and only if, you know what you're getting into. Surprisingly pretty mild for Lush, and the crazy intensity doesn't last that long. Situationship personified in a bottle. Maybe that's why it's attracting all the wlw folks like a moth to a flame. Side note: pairs EXTREMELY well with fresh fruity clean shampoo scents.

Stunning I have had some many good compliments when wearing this it’s such a beautiful polarising fragrance it’s cozy in cold wether but cooling in warm wether I will always have a bottle of this in my collection

i've been daily wearing this basically all summer (southern hemisphere) and i have, oh, just a couple thoughts.

1. this is the biggest compliment getter i've ever worn. like seriously, i've gotten multiple compliments from the same person on the same DAY wearing this, that's how well-received it is, which is interesting because here it seems fairly polarizing. i will say that in my case it is noticed almost exclusively by women (the one man that I've had comment on it was a gay man, so take that how you will) and the women who seem the most drawn to it are basically always queer. as someone who appears pretty femme in my daily life, i Love that this scent mascs me up a bit, but I think i'd be happy to smell it on almost any kind of gender presentation, it's a true unisex scent.

2. pairs FANTASTICALLY with a good sunscreen scent. i wear full body sunscreen every day in summer so this discovery happened organically, but i love layering this with anything in the coconut + white florals scent family (SDJ 81, MM Beach Walk, TF Soleil Blanc etc.) and it also plays very nicely with more intense white or yellow florals (Salty + Lust is my favourite night out combo right now)

3. i keep coming back to the oud in this. it's hilarious in that oud is so divisive, and this is divisive, but oud lovers do not seem to be drawn to this. I'd argue it's closer to sandalwood, or a true "driftwood" scent if that's even possible. to get out of the oceanic metaphors (which I think are a little limiting for representing what this scent actually is) it smells like spending hours working up a sweat on a woodchip playground with some white florals planted on the outskirts.

in conclusion - gorgeous scent, great performance, perfect for those of us who want a "summer scent" without having to give up on woody, heady gorgeousness.

Okay, full disclosure, I got this because I read multiple comments around the Internet saying that queer women love this (and as a queer woman, I feel compelled to explore anything that gets the community's seal of approval), but I'm gonna need someone to explain this one to me. I guess I get how this could smell "clean sweaty" but TBH I think my actual clean sweaty body on its own smells better than this. Will keep testing because why not, I already blind bought the bottle, but I think I'm gonna have to break ranks here.

As for how it actually smells: it's a little oud-y (but oud lite) in the beginning, so slightly funky, but the dry down is dried ocean water on skin, salty and still a little funky, but now in that way that beaches are a little funky because of all the decaying seaweed and crab exoskeletons. I'm not getting any neroli or rose, unfortunately.

Edit: kokokoko's review below really nails the opening lol, is that why the lesbians are into this?

This blew me away. I've received so many compliments when wearing this and I need to get a backup bottle asap... I don't have anything that smells even remotely close to this!

The vibes this gives off is imagine being on a Greek island, you've just had the most amazing day at the beach, going back and forth into the water, the sweat beads all over you being washed off by the water, you dry off under the Aegean sun on a tanning bed... Then you and your significant other rush off back to your villa to have a very quick shower before you both just absolutely ravage the hell out of each other before heading off to enjoy the hot summer night at a Greek eatery along the water... THATS the vibe this gives you. Its a sexy animalic scent that just lingers and stays with you. My wife goes absolutely feral when I wear this, as do I when she sprays it on herself! Its an absolute love, a gem from Lush that not many people bother to try.

Oudh and Salt. Imagination exercise.

Salty body spray smells 90% like oudh and 10% like salt.

This is the first fragrance I've ever smelled that actually smells salty. There are many fragrances marketed as ''salty'', especially the ones that are created around a beach or seashore theme, but none of them actually smell like salt.
Salty does.
I think Salty is in the top 3 best body sprays Lush sells.
But where would I wear this? It gives me the vibe of a day by the sea in the dessert. Dubai, Oman, Qatar. Other than that, it beats my imagination. Suggestions?

Ordered this today because no stores near me were carrying it and I see what everyone in the comments is talking about this is pure human secretions absolutely animalic. smells like salty saliva and vaginal fluids. I'm not sure in a good way for me personally. Then within 10 minutes I'm getting alot of powdery oud. It's not bad at that point.

So I went to Lush today, sprayed this on my arm and wasn't sure what to think. Ended up leaving with Honey I Washed The Kids and Lord of Misrule. THEN on the drive home I couldn't stop smelling myself where I sprayed Salty... Now I'm at home and I regret not buying it! The dry down on Salty is really addictive to me... Safe to say I'll be buying a bottle very soon.

This is probably my favourite lush scent they sell! This smells like a woman who smells really good whilst you're travelling, and you end up thinking of her and the scent the rest of the day. This scent has made me realise my hidden love for oud! Love!

I f**king love it. I think it’s such a great spring/summer scent, more to wear during the day but would work perfectly for summer evenings and nights. Smells great on women and very sensual on men too. It opens more masculine but dries towards more sweet and flowery. Everyone who smelled it on me or when I sprayed it had the same reaction - “It smells like the sea and summer!”, without knowing what it was or what the name of it was. I read in some reviews that people feel it’s too strong at times which I can understand. However, I’d just say that it’s its silage and longevity rather than just strength, you can definitely layer it to smell it more or less based on what you prefer.

This is pissy and floral in a really, really old fashioned perfumery sort of way that I don't typically expect from Lush, which is kind of nice. I'm disappointed though, because there is no oud--listen to Lush's description, not this one, as the only wood I detect is this marine sort of sandalwood, or more particularly dry, salty driftwood--and Salty is definitely the right name for it. I actually quite like it but for me it's too weak to wear as a perfume, so I plan to use it as a linen spray.

This is such a gem!! It’s like the chypres of yore, but so different, and so good! The name is aptly chosen as it is and stays salty throughout.

It opens indeed with a smell that is reminiscent of sweaty skin, but in a good way! It’s not like body odour, it’s sensual sweatiness, mixed in with salt. It’s the smell of someone who is spending a day at the beach, sweaty, salty, bronzed body. It’s so addictive that I keep sniffing and am tempted to lick my skin to taste the salt.

While it’s definitely not feminine leaning, as there is absolutely no sweetness at all, I consider this squarely unisex. What makes a perfume masculine to me, is if there are certain notes that are only found in male perfumes. Those are most common in blue perfumes for men, and give that typical male cologne smell. None of that is present here, it’s just a very natural smelling chypre, without any sweetness.

The opening lasts long and the salt in this stage is the most present. There’s something else too, which I’m sure is the oud, though it doesn’t really smell like oud to me in this perfume; it smells like driftwood. It’s also very mossy in this stage, which makes sense, because oakmoss in perfumes always smells a bit salty to my nose.

Once the salt settles down after the very long opening (2.5 hours), the driftwood comes forward more, and so does the neroli. The neroli is present in this stage, but subdued. Rather than taking centre stage, it plays a supporting role ; adding a layer to the driftwood smell and creating the illusion of a salty gentle sea breeze, that carries just a hint of the smell of neroli with it.

Slowly the rose develops too. A crisp, dry rose, but not powdery. It’s a white rose to my nose. It’s not lush, jammy or thick, but delicate and subtle. In this stage the scent becomes more elegant and refined, and very very beautiful.

It dries down quite dark and musky, with the smell of almost rotting driftwood and sea water. This is not a fragrance to make you smell pretty, this is a fragrance to transport you to a place and setting and I love it!

I’m definitely going to get a full bottle of this juice. It’s an amazing, interesting scent that’s well worth the price and lasts very long.

Very masculine. Its reminiscent of salty sweaty skin. Its an oud but more of a musky oud than a strong dark oud. Its more of a sweaty person who has been in the sun & went swimming in the ocean rather than having a proper shower.

This one's so fuckable. It in honestly embarrassing how fuckable this is. This smells like riding someone's thigh. If it's rose, it's a rose that someone with a flashy lipstick just bit into, holding it in between their lips. Oud gives it this bodily, musky sort of dirtiness; and neroli keeps it fun and light, in "don't get attached" sort of way. This is a perfume to spray on your ankles. I would say I love it, but it would probably reject me after that.

I wanted to like this but I can't. I don't like the opening in particular because it has a woody, aftershave smell. If you're sensitive to oud, use it sparingly. Thank god it doesn't last, after a while it starts to smell more floral but it's still too masculine for me. Not the tropical, beachy smell I was looking for. A blind buy which I regret.

Not bad for the price. I’d say it reminds me of a surf shop that also sells bongs and essential oils, if you know what I mean. I think the name is pretty fitting. It’s woody and salty at the same time. The rose is very soft, and not cheap or prominent. I wouldn’t notice it if it wasn’t mentioned.

Headache inducing on my skin, rather try before you buy.
Definitely loooong lasting.

This smells like if you had gone to a beach party, danced until the sun threatened to shine a light on your debauchery. You wake up a bit salty Sandy and a bit sticky, you take a dip in the sea to refresh and ‘wake up’ then you let your skin dry in the mid morning heat. This, this is that smell that smell of skin with sally elements - it’s got a stink but a sexy stink.

7/10

I wanted to love it! But I get the worst headache and nausea when I wear it. I don’t get any other notes beside oud on me. Plus it’s very long lasting and projecting so you only need 2-3 hits. Not a bad fragrance at all…just makes me sick sadly.

Oh well this is intimate isn’t it?

I never smelled Salarium, but Salty is exactly what I’ve been looking for in a perfume. Uncomplicated, sexy, understated, woody, incensey. It smells like that natural after-sex smell, if you’d had sex in a beautiful hotel on a beach, with the slightly salty night wind flowing in through the window. God I love it so much. I cannot believe this is £30 for 200ml. Buying a full bottle as soon as I finish my sample.

I own the shaving cream form of Salty/Salarium 2.0, Shaved Ice. The scent really grew on me as I really love Oud-based scents. Owning a couple oud oils from the SE.Asia region has deepened my appreciation for Oud, and this is one that is a keeper.

The smooth, salty accords harmonises with a light and elegant oud note presented in Salty. The scent stays uniform throughout its longevity, only dwindling in terms of its projection.

Understandably, the bottle (Salarium) was costly due to ingredient constraints and this would be somewhat of a middle ground for those who love its scent but may not be agreeable to its costs (in comparison to Lush's other compositions).

This is a much much cheaper version of Salarium which is going to be discontinued in my country. Love the scent as it's really not bad! A linear scent which is quite well blended. I'm really not sure how to describe the scent.. I didn't get the salty animalic feel. I had the initial impression of a much lighter version of MFK's Oud Silk Mood, but no. This is really different and pleasant and I can't stop going back to sniff the paper strip.

I don't get the notes listed here. I get musk and salt, maybe aldehydes too? a very intimate smell, kind of like hair/scalp and vintage clothes, but not in a bad way. The barnyard accord that we get in Lush Kerbside Violet is here in Salty too, but much more subtle. I love this scent. This makes me think of a sexual conquest: someone you never thought would reciprocate interest, but there you are, with them, letting you get close. You never even thought you'd be in their orbit, but they're consenting, letting you close enough to inhale their scent. This is a gorgeous scent, unisex, and I love it.

First scent gives pine definitely in a resin or bark way, woody, I really like resin-y pine smell in this, there's more vanilla then I like but it's ok and not too sweet for this scent. Helps keep it more unisex then feminine.

Overall deep and slightly fresh or intense outdoors scent of fallen pine needles, bark, with strong vanilla base that lasts on my clothes until the next day. Wish there was more green or sharp notes. The lime is nice, but fades and turns into fruity background. Personally feels too warm base/vanilla for my preference but nice in autumn.

Prefer wearing on my skin. Lasts a decent time,
Strong scent from first spray.

How I hated this. The original Assassin (a shower gel) from Lush was woody and green perfection with depth, and without the addition of the horrendous sweet and fruity notes. The original was truly like a walk in the forest. We weren't told about the change at first and quite a few purchased the perfume excitedly because we loved the original. I am glad it was discontinued and never brought back, as were many. (The original thankfully did return in a subscription box once.)

I wish this scent got more attention. It is one of the most interesting black currant scents I wore. It is like a walk through an abandoned garden, there are no flowers there, just overgrown plants and grass, wet soil and rotten leaves, there is also a pine tree but first of all there is this strong prominent sweet black currant juice. It was discontinued for good as it was only limited edition :(((( I am sure more people would have discovered this gem if it had been sold in all Lush stores. I will always miss you Assassin.
This starts out as if we're the base for Christian Dior's Poison kinda beautiful and then a soft spicy woody scent developed on me , I am very intrigued.

I have a bottle of the liquid EDP. I love the comforter as a bubble bar,so I was very exited about this perfume. And while it does smell a bit similar,it just doesnt have the same warmth to it. I see many people write about cat pee, licourice, bergamot and herbs, but I don't get any of that. To me,this is not layered at all. All I get is a very "thin" Black currant juice with some vanilla,and it mostly dries down to a sweet vanilla scent,and that's it. Not unpleasant at all, but very simple and child-like,to me.

I'm reviewing the body spray here. It mostly smells like blackcurrant to me. I can see where people get the cat pee from I guess, but it's only when I really think about it. I wore this a lot spring of 2020 when covid first hit the States, a very bittersweet time in many of our lives. It may have been stressful beginning to the year, but I got to spend lots more time outdoors in that bright old sun, with my partner whom I just started dating at the time, with this amazing fruity-green body spray. Every time I smell it now, it brings back those memories. I wanna buy a full bottle again some time soon for this coming season
Extremely strong, extremely sweet, black as fuck blackcurrant. No idea why anyone is talking about cats.

Folks, the 'cat pee' being smelled is coming from the black currant accord. Black currant scent profile per Fragrantica: "A tangy fruit note with a very characteristic ammoniac "cat piss" nuance sourced from green leaf buds." I despise black currant in fragrances for the very reason of that description because my nose is hypersensitive to such smells. I do find that when the fragrance pyramid indicates a scent has the leaves, the scent is more tolerable, but I still get a 'catty' undercurrent. I'm not sure why perfumers gravitate toward black currant rather than using blackberry, but I wish it would fall out of favor...

I know EXACTLY what people are talking about, when they say they can smell “cat pee”. BUT, it’s the “green” in the fragrance. If you’ve ever walked around, back in the bush, you can smell it on really hot days. It comes from the green on wild fruit, weeds, and some flowers. Some people even think it smells a little “skunky”, like a pot plant. I think their goal was to make it smell real, rather than synthetic. And they did a good job imo. Yes it’s a little “skanky”, but I actually like that. If someone is just wanting to get into some “skank” THIS is now the one I would recommend. It’s STILL fruity, but the scent really does remind me of a hot, and sweaty day in the sun. So it’s a LITTLE dirtyISH, but not really!?!?
up for swap,pm me if u are interested

Bought the solid and yeah, cat pee. Thought I'd try it anyway in case my nose was just being crazy and it smelled all weird and herb-ish on top of the pee smell.

Really hate Lush's "limited edition" shenanigans because the ebayers are killing me.

Anyone know how to get rid of the pee smell? Melt it down maybe?

Because the Comforter bubble bar and lotion, and the "You Snap the Whip" all smelled fantastic!

Edit: Just bought a bottle of the liquid -that arrived broken all to hell, but managed to save maybe a third of it- and while it is really, really sweet smelling I'm still getting hint of cat pee. Wtf is up with this perfume? The liquid isn't nearly as bad as the solid, but damn. Something in this is ruining the scent.

I have the solid version of this fragrance. It is a bit licorice-like at first, but then it develops into something creamy, fruity, and soft. I am a huge bergamot fan, and I do get a bit of that. I enjoy this fragrance, but it doesn't last all day. Since it is a solid, I can toss it in my purse to refresh, though. I can't comment on the liquid version, sadly.

I blind bought this online in 2012 during the Lush forum special sale that year (I say that in order to establish that the perfume was fresh, presumably no issues with it). I got a very strong cat urine odor with it, just nothing but cat pee -- some other reviews on the web say this as well. I wish I'd sought out more reviews before buying it, oh well. It's definitely one to try before you buy.

This is the same scent of Lush's best selling bubble bar.

I love it! There's a liquorice accord to it which i love (Try Lush's 'Lord of the Goathorn' if you're also a liquorice fan!) as well as the blackcurrants mmmm :)

I was lucky enough to buy a few bottles of this at the Gorilla pop up shop at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival last year.
RIP Potion. I'll never forget how I doused myself in you in the mid-2000s :(
impossible for me to describe but quite lovely. natural smelling but not in a patchouli/granola way.
opening is ok, the rest is just straight up typical chilean old grandpa. i hate it

i initially walked into lush looking for guardian of the forest body spray, as i have been longing to smell like a druid. unfortunately, they were out of stock. which led me to pansy.. love at first spray. i find that it just melts into the skin, the rosemary note is particularly pronounced on me, hints of white musk. i dislike perfumes that make me smell of..perfume. i prefer intimate, skin scents - easily found in nature. pansy ticks all my boxes. it is warm and earthy, it reminds me of the lillith fair, very 90s singer songwriter. this is my new go to perfume

This smells like clean laundry but the laundry was done in a river in the forest. And the soap was made from flowers and herbs. And the laundry was line dried in a clearing with wildflowers. Can you tell this is my favorite perfume?

Pansy is lovely. It is so SOFT! I'm in my late 20s and love old lady scents - though sometimes they can be a bit overwhelming. However Pansy feels like the perfect substitute for that. It has a sense of wiseness to it, some sophistication. It feels like it pairs well with talking about old memories. Having said that it smells like an old perosn, I feel like the said person would be someone a bit quirky and Earthy! It is certainly complimentary to natural body odour, it sits very nicely. It makes me want to frolic through a field with my partner.

This is pretty musky to my nose. Not a lot of mentions of that. Also soapy. Unfortunately the green, fresh rosemary notes fade pretty quickly. Wish I wouldn't have bought a 100 ml bottle before testing it out a few times. Not saying it's bad but it's not good either.

this is such a baffling and sexy scent. the rosemary comes across super strong to me so it reminds me of like a middle aged mountain woman who has an herb garden and washes her hands frequently. this could be the scent of a hand soap. however i can’t stop smelling it on me for some reason i think it fabulously complements the scent of skin rather than competing with natural stink or “smelling like perfume.” it just smells like part of you and makes you feel measurably more grown-womanly and alluring. spray this on some hot skin in store because a test strip doesn’t even give you half of it
I wore this on my first date with my now long term partner and I do believe this greatly influenced how well it went

This is an unbelievably sexy fragrance in my very humble opinion. I don’t love perfume. I definitely don’t love straight up florals. I’m usually into fruity body sprays. But this, oh my gosh! It smells like the hottest person you know, male or female, has gotten sweaty picking oranges but they showered right before and the phermones compliment their bougie soap perfectly. It’s clean but natural, simple but elevated. I smell citrus and the cleanest, slightly powdery musk.

The bright opening of bergamot, not overly sour, is paired with the sharp, slightly bitter edge of galbanum though not too green. This is followed by a soft touch of rosemary and orange flower that never feels overwhelming. The bergamot only flash by briefly I wish the opening lingered a little longer because it feels so fresh and uplifting before transitioning into a gentle floral-herbal blend, resting on a light oakmoss base that isn’t as strong as in vintage fougère or barbershop fragrances (a style I truly love). Labdanum further softens the base, giving Pansy an even smoother dry-down.

The scent lasts around 4–6 hours and projects well around first 1-2 hours, It’s a soft, gentle fragrance built from floral and herbal notes—never offensive, never too forceful, and always friendly.

This is perfect for rainy days. It's herbal, sweet, fresh and cosy at the same time, it does smell like being in a garden centre in a way. I love that it's a little tart from the blackberry note <3

The longevity is excellent and the projection is moderate, which is nice as I feel it could end up being a little suffocating if it were stronger. I really really like this - in the summer it's a bit much but it's perfect for wet, spring days.

Like a bouquet of wild flowers!
Beautifully herbal, floral, and a bit tangy.

Pansy is such a fitting name, love this a lot.

LOVE this scent. I have the solid version. Herbal and creamy, white flowers but not too floral forward, very refreshing, clean, calming scent. I see how some could find it slightly soapy, but I don't find this to be too soapy on my skin (and I hate soapy). Very wearable for year-round but great for spring/summer. Smells like a very pretty girl in a white dress on vacation, at a nice hotel, reading a very sad book. Reminds me of 34 Boulevard St Germain by Diptyque.

unknown slayer, i only bought this because i loved "The Olive Branch" by Lush because share the same scent. i do think its the best scent from Lush for a body wash. this scent is probably what the mediterranean smelled like in the 1960's or 1970's, citrus tree-lined along the coast, with that bergamot and blackberry, but i do prefer this scent on the body wash.
yum... sometimes it's too floral for me but rn in the height of summer it's perfect. i wear it when i'm feeling like a pansy <3
The dry down of this on my hands is reminding me here and there of Cacharel's Eden, only calmer and more wearable. I really love this fragrance!
Unfortunately this smells like sunscreen to me :(

90s, but not vintage smelling. Natural, herby soap vibes, but not obviously "Lush" branded. Opens up smelling like the classic brown Neutrogena Rainbath, but mellows and sweetens a bit on the drydown to smell like you're walking around with bag of the prettiest smelling handmade soaps at the farmer's market. It is subtle, though. I wear this constantly.

The first fragrance I think I bought with my own grown up money, this was love at first sniff <3 The note of rosemary is just so nostalgic, like a hot summer’s day in a small Mediterranean seaside town surrounded by my dad, my yayo and cousins around some food and drinks.

Obviously, big fan of the name too, duh ;)

I really liked this perfume when i tested it at the store. For the very first few minutes it smelled very herbal, green, rather 'masculine'. Then it got more delicate and floral.
Unfortunately, after 30 minutes on my skin it started smelling like my late alcoholic grandpa giving me an unwanted hug at a family reunion. Like a slightly sweaty old man right after he shaves and puts on some perfume.
Needless to say, I'm glad I didn't immediately buy this.

This feels like swimming in the deep part of the Atlantic in the middle of July or August. I wish it was a little bit more bright and airy, more orange blossom but still I expect this to be a good summer scent for the mountains this year.

This very quickly becomes an intimate green, sweet powdery scent on the skin. I have to add some on my clothes to keep around some of the herbal, candy-like notes that project a bit more.

I feel it lacks something, but layers well with Nishane's Wulong Cha, and is very comforting, like scented talc. More of a personal scent than a going out scent.

It reminds me of Foin Fraichement Coupe by Oriza.

May, 2025
Spain
Solid version

Heavy and soapy. But pretty.

I imagine a bar of soap that’s been sitting next to a vase of cut herbs and flowers that are going to be used for a dinner.

Update: dried heavy galbannum (sorry, spelling) - mixed w a little of “dirty” and it was amazing.

I’ve been wearing this for over two years now, always in spring/summer, becoming my signature scent. It reminds me of the mediterranean sea, when you‘re on the walk, you catch a hint of flowers from someone’s garden and life feels easy. It‘s fresh, calming and somehow warm too.

Despite having relatively few notes, they are all clear to notice while being well blended together. The blackberry, bergamot and orange blossom provide subtle freshness, then there is herbal rosemary giving a bit of spice to almost powdery flowers and labdanum or oak moss giving it a creamier base. As some reviewers said, the dry-down is different from the initial spray, though i personally love both. The green herbal curtain and the flowers you get when it opens.

It starts of strong with the Rosemary note being very dominant. It makes it smell more maskulin at first. But as it dries down it is more of a slightly sweet, citrus, floral and herbal scent.
The scent does indeed remind me a bit a bit of soap.

Gorgeous. So close to being my signature scent if I could have two I would. I have this in soap and perfume I love it that much. Warm, fresh and comforting this perfume lets you know with its bergamot opening & orange blossom introduction that it’s uplifting your mood, the other smells are defo floral but background features to the orange blossom & bergamot which take centre stage encouraging the freshness while the florals dance quietly in the background.
Stunning

Used to be my fave around 2021/2022—all comforting and mellow, like a good hug; however, either Lush changed the formula or covid's done its damage, this perfume is now so unpleasantly sharp, I can't stand it on my skin. I still use it on fabric, but it just isn't the same.

an underrated gem from lush. This is soapy, green, bitter but with a thorny blackberry, and dry herbaceousness from the galbanum. Best worn in Spring, but works as equally well for a chilled, late afternoon on a lazy day in Autumn.

I recently got a solid perfume of this and this is everything I wanted in a spring summer perfume. Aromatic yet sweet, light but grounded and maybe a bit heavy but I don’t mind. I really can’t stop smelling it, it’s also a little powdery in a clean luxurious way. Wish I got this sooner during the spring.

Edit: I finally got a bottle of this and I want it to be the scent that reminds me of my trip to santa cruz with my partner.

Kept wondering why it smelled familiar and then had a lightbulb & smell checked it against the ever present enormous bottle of Neutrogena Rainbath under my sink- bingo! The resemblance is especially apparent upon initial spritz, with it losing that sharper spiced edge later in the dry down. Warm, comforting, spiced as if with dried nutmeg and clove baking spices...and a hint dusty, like the back of an old wood drawer- as someone who loves antiques, that works for me! Perhaps the back of one of the drawers in my great grandmother's bathroom vanity.
Beautiful, nostalgic type smell. I've never tried the other Lush bath products containing the same scent, but as someone who has previously searched for a perfume that evoked Rainbath- how happy to have accidentally come upon this!
Somewhat ephemeral on skin (perhaps 3 to 4 hours?), but lasts well on clothes.
I feel like a lot of lush scents have some discordant notes that settle down after an hour or so. The dry down of this is extremely pretty, but I don't really like the initial spray.

I mean, of course it smells soapy, after all it is a LUSH fragrance. But its dry and herbal and very overpowering. It is unisex and sweet in a way, but I personally feel like the rosemary note makes it a bit masculine leaning, but it is definitely in the unisex realm. I see in the votes and comments that this reminds of the shower gel ‘Olive branch’, also from LUSH, and that is spot on.

This is an early morning jog in the mediterraneans, and then a nice shower followed by your new thick olive body butter, and then eating breakfast under a citrus tree.

Opens unpleasantly sharp and green, perhaps this greenness is rosemary — but it doesn’t really read that like to me, but nearly immediately begins to sweeten and take on a gourmand quality. This fragrance reminds me of those old-fashioned lemon and violet candies that come in metal tin. Over time the citrus mellows into the background and the galbanum takes center stage, turning the fragrance into something muskier. It settles into a very wearable creamy, powdery floral.

The overall combination of notes isn’t very interesting for me, but sometimes when reaching for an everyday scent, you don’t want something remarkable. This would be good year round, but especially suitable in summer and spring. It’s a girlishly feminine fragrance, but in a short of old-fashioned way. There is a youthfulness to the fragrance that keeps it from wandering over into grandma territory. Silage is close, but longevity is not great, 2ish hours for me.

Soft, sweet, clean, cozy, creamy, powdery white floral with the signature Lush twinge. A mild well-rounded perfume that can be worn regardless of age, season, or occasion. Probably one of their least eccentric/funky/hippie-esque fragrances. You could even do a blind buy here.

Opening is interesting but unpleasant (sharp sour/sweet bug repellant) but the drydown is a nice powdery chypre, although with a slight bitternesstjat I'm not too fond of. Overall the most interesting/nuanced scent from Lush

Very unisex and I can smell each and every one of the notes. Very light, neutral. Greatly balanced between floral, herbal, fruity and citrusy. Also has something masculine about it but in a very boyish way. If only it wouldnt last 0.5 seconds. Id recommend purchasing a solid version.

Who would have thought that rosemary will be such a great scent in a perfume. This is very aromatic but grounded. I like it, my go to fragrance at home. I use it at work sometimes when I'm getting stressed, it's calming. For some reason, it works really well with my chemistry. It turns a bit musky but the scents gets deeper, smells sexy after a while. You start smelling like a bath bomb, then it gets sexier.

My fave lush scents:
American Cream (when I feel pretty)
Karma (when I'm super stressed and I need to be alone)
Twilight (makes me sleep really deep)
Sikkim Girls (I miss this scent! Super sexy, bring it back!)
Pansy (soapy and sexy)

Not a huge fan of floral scents but this one strikes me as more warm and herbal than floral. Feels almost like Karma's more springy sister. To my nose, top notes are ambery orange peel, middle are patchouli and base are leathery pine. It's a very robust Lush coded scent. A friend of mine dislikes it as it smells like a "granny" to her. I do agree that it smells somewhat old-timey (but not granny-like) and something about it just translates to 60s Mod and yellow floral wallpaper to me. Lasts for ages on me! Always a winner.

super wearable; a great balance between powdery and green. smells like you took bubble bath in ancient rome. very springy but could really be worn year round, as the powdery notes make themselves known within about an hour of wear. the true dry down of the musk + powder + slight floral nature is divine. another visual: imagine if someone sprinkled baby powder on a fragrant patch of moss.

(Reviewing the solid version.) I only got to spend a few days with this fragrance before it got ran over by a car. On paper, this should be an absolute winner for me. In reality, I just get florals and old cigarettes. No real drydown, just a fadeaway, but another reviewer said that they got noseblind to it and the smell definitely stuck around for longer, so maybe that's what happened. I can't really relate to these notes at all, but I suspect that might be a formulation problem with the solid version. A tiny, tiny smidge of solid Dirty on top of this helped bring a little bit of life to the bergamot and rosemary here, but that thick dusty nicotine-stained quilt of Pansy was very much still present.
bau macam hantu pocong
I've noticed the smell seems to have changed - smells much more like grass now and less floral?
The dry down of this parfum really reminds me of live don’t be shy by Killian. I’m the only one who has this impression?

This really works on me. I stop smelling it about 2 hours in, but people keep commenting on how good it smells 6+ hours later. I like to layer it with Lust. 3 sprays Pansy to 1 spray Lust. Lasts ALL day. People say i smell like I just came in from frolicking in a gardenia bush, bathed in sunlight. I'll take that.

Hmm. I have the solid perfume so I think I'm getting notes of chapstick, paper, and warmth because of that element. Outside of that it's bright. Floral and citrus smell without being too sweet. I like it

Rich floral with some sultry warm undertones. Easy to wear on a daily basis, smells clean. Could be worn any season but especially when plants are lush and full in spring and summer.This is my favorite reach in the spring, especially when spritzed on the hair. For a very lush green floral experience, combine with the Happy Happy Joy Joy conditioner.

Gah! I wish I could enjoy this perfume with the rest of you (I love the shower gel) but it always pulls so masculine on me... Dry, herbal, leathery... I can smell the fruitiness from the bottle but once it hits my skin it's only there for 15-30 minutes and even then it's faint, the base notes dominate right from the start. :( Has good longevity though, about 6 hours but doesn't disappear completely until 7-8 hours.

If you're familiar with Lush perfumes, to me this is like a mix of Orange Blossom and Devil's Nightcap.

Interesting fragrance.

Starts out an aromatic - similar to Aqua di Parma Colonia or 4711 cologne - petitgrain/citrus/bergamot heavy. The unusual part is then the creamy, soft, woody vanilla comes out. That is why I can’t decide if I love this fragrance or not. The 4711 vibe mixed with creamy vanilla confuses my nose lol.

Pansy is a bit of a misnomer - it is not a very green nor is it a floral fragrance. Everyone says it is similar to Olive Branch and that would’ve been a better name for this perfume imo. Because it does evoke the Mediterranean- smells like someone wearing Acaua di Parma while eating vanilla panacotta.

This is lovely, the opening is very herbal with a slight hint of citrus, the middle is mostly citrusy with a hint of fruitiness, and the base is a light citrusy amber. For a Lush perfume it's quite transformative. My only complaint is that I wish that the herbal phase lasted a bit longer, I only really get it for a few minutes.
I would say that this is actually an amber perfume rather than herbal because of how quickly I get that base. The amber in the base reminds me a lot of L’Ambre des Merveilles by Hermes.

Since I love the scent of Lush The Olive Branch and heard Pansy had some similiarity I dove in and bought a bottle.
I can detect the rich spicy deep orange from Branch but it is combined with a bit of sweetness I'm guessing is from the blackberry at the heart.
This is really nice!
Aromatic and joyful.
I only wish it were a stronger performer.
✨

An herbal and citrusy floral. It's very bright and fresh but not obnoxiously so, other reviewers have noted that Lush perfumes have a sort of earthiness to them, and that's what I love about em. It's very grounding. The body lotion in this scent is great too.

A bright and sunny floral citrus opening with a herbal undercurrent. I've been enjoying using this during the summer months as it's quite a fresh and light linear fragrance. As I find with quintessential Lush fragrances there is a 'dirty' note that can be an acquired taste.

To me, the beginning smells very male-leaning unisex. A bit fruity and citrusy, then it dries down and the coumarin shows up, I was surprised to find it pleasant.
I'm not a big fan of the coumarin, vanilla or buttery/gourmand kinda scents as those smell sticky, overwhelming and could be nauseating to me, but Pansy's the first perfume from my personal no-go scents that I could see myself wearing. So I picked this up for whenever I need a change of mood as it gives me a soothing, cozy feel, like drinking chocolate or caramel milk.
On me, the smell stays close to my skin and lasts about 3 hrs before it becomes powdery and barely noticeable. Not bad, but also not impressed either.

I wish I could agree with other reviews that this smells good in the dry down but it just doesn't.. I love citrus fragrances but this specifically smells truly chemical. Not to offend but It actually reminds me of cheap public bathroom hand soap or air freshener. Everyone's describing this as cozy and it just ain't. Floral citrus hand soap.

This is the same fragrance as The Olive Branch, sweet and herbal and a little powdery. I really like this fragrance in other LUSH products, unfortunately it feels too intense for me to wear and smell constantly as a perfume.
Gorgeous floral fruity herbal fragrance. I wish it lasted longer though.

Wow! This is just one of those perfumes I cannot stop smelling. It’s very sensual but still fresh. Smells warm and earthy. I tried this fragrance on a trip to the mall and decided to stop by lush. I sampled all of the fragrances but this was a stand out to me. The Labdanum really makes this fragrance for me. If you are a bergamot lover as I am but want something a little sexier this is it. Definitely might become my signature scent.

I loved this in the store. Hugely green but with a dusting of beautiful florals. I bought it immediately.

Unfortunately by the time I got in my car the frag had disappeared entirely. So I tried again the next day - same thing. Within 20 minutes the smell is totally, completely gone, vanished like a gentle fart in the wind. I’ll be returning it.

[Pansy]
⚫️⚫️⚫️⚫️⚪️

Reminds me of Prin’s work for Strangers Parfumerie. In the vein of Oliver, Aroon Sawat and more so Les marvais Garçons.

Burst of fresh fruits
Orange Blossom
Coumarin dry down.
Could be mistaken for Nivea cream.

An interesting summer stunner.
Nice grounding scent , alas a limited edition. Unisex and very natural smelling. One of LUSH's better florals. Pansy feels "purple and green" all at once.
Smells exactly like cat litter to me - blegh!
Not very remarkable.

Such a nice and pretty floral fragrance! Quite green and fresh in the opening with the bergamot, then it settles to this sweeter (but not too sweet) orange blossom and blackberry that honestly I just love. Just perfect for spring and summer days! I have to say it doesn’t last too long on me, but for its price it’s definitely a steal.
not for me ugh im not too keen on earthy scents but that seems to be lush’s specialty

Pansy is sooo pretty. There is a sweet fruity vanillic basenote that’s not really listed here and even though I don’t like sweet scents that much, it is given so much floral, spicy, smoky, and dark depth by the labdanum, galbanum and citrus that line the fringes of this perfume, adding mystery and allure to its aura. This is truly a one of a kind feminine perfume and totally signature scent worthy. And it’s made of healthy ingredients to boot.
Opens very green and bitter, with a hint of blackberry. When it settles, the orange blossom comes through, and with the blackberry, it becomes a pretty, sweet floral.

I’m a huge fan of Lush’s Olive branch shower gel. But recently (idk if it’s just me) i felt like the smell isn’t as strong as it used to be. Years ago, when i used the shower gel my bathroom would have clouds of olive branch for hours.. now it’s so weak!

So i searched up online for perfumes that smell like it. Lo and behold i found pansy. I was so giddy when pansy arrived at my doorstep. I sprayed it on AND WOW! It does smell super duper close to the olive branch. However i find it creamier.. the reviews below me nailed it. It smells like cake. The cake/gourmand version of the olive branch. It’s strong.. seriously. It has a huge sillage and great longevity imo. Typical Lush!

Pansy smells to me like ginger cake. I have no idea why as there is no ginger in the ingredients list. I can smell citrus and rosemary as well. I don’t get any powdery notes. To my nose it is linear. I think it is unusual and definitely not for everyone and I wouldn’t wear it everyday. I feel like the best situation to wear it is in winter by the fire, feeling cosy and relaxed. In my opinion it is quite heavy fragrance and not suitable for summer. I also wouldn’t call it unisex. I think it is more feminine. It stays on skin and clothes for a decent amount of time.

I love galbanum. Pansy opens with a blast of green leaves and galbanum. I’d never actually place the Rosemary. I guess mixed with the orange blossom it simply becomes slightly astringent green, and then it moves towards a slightly powdery, herbal-floral balance. I had an Aunt Pansy, not a blood relation, but she was a very sweet person. And this reminds me of her and her back yard when we used to visit her when I was a child. Sunny and green and mossy. Did I mention I love galbanum?
The green note is pleasant on paper but wearing on skin or clothes, quite off-putting. Has elements that remind me of sunny side that I wish were brightened/amped up

I loved the olive branch as a solid perfume and was devastated when i realized that they would stop selling it. Tried some copies and also Lush's re-make a couple of years ago but didn't really like the copies, and the re-make smelled like cat pee on me. Pansy as a solid perfume does not last at all. I had high hopes on this one, but i think it has a strong scent of anise(?) which i don't like at all in this one. And it is not as soft and cozy and balanced as i find the old olive branch solid perfume.

Not at all what I was expecting for the name, pansies have this overpoweringly sickly honeyed scent. But this Pansy was a pleasant surprise - it opens up with a blast of crushed green leaves, if its the blackberry its the fresh leaves of the plant, its actually very nice, almost nettle like. At the same time there is sweetness, neroli orangey sweetness and these two main note themes make a really lovely contrast for each other. I wish it would stay like this for a bit longer but sadly the longevity on me is quite weak. It also does not project much so this one remains a private joy, says she bringing her wrist to her nose for another dose of this verdant beauty. Its lovely, if a bit hidden.

What. A. Disappointment.
For a dude, I really like floral scents. I like to blur the gender boundaries. This one is sickly syrupy and thick, sugary-sweet, cloying urinal cake crossed with cheap valentines heart candies and glade plug-ins... its sharp and unbalanced, and has this trashy and cheap musk background that makes it smell like the perfume from Mattel sold with the barbie dolls. Its just bad. Beginning to end, absolutely terrible.

I bought several of the solid perfumes today at Lush, and while I like the scent of most that I bought, I don't like that they all start out smelling like Crayola crayons. That must be the wax that is used. This is the worst offender. While it does lighten up, it seems to be running beneath the surface when I smell where I applied it. It's pretty off-putting. Once it lightens up to where I can smell the perfume, it reminds me of a spa scent. Citrusy, aromatic, slightly sweet, slightly floral, and slightly powdery; very formulaic. I tried the liquid version in the store, but the problem with this brand is that the sprays seem to give enormous silage that's almost overwhelming, and combined with all the other scents in the store it's hard to get a good read on what you're actually smelling. Since the solid was cheap enough I bought it so I could try it at home. Figured, if I didn't like it, not much was lost. We'll, I'm not crazy about the scent and compounding the dislike is that waxy Crayola crayon smell. Oh well, live and learn. Thank goodness it was cheap.

I don't know why but this (solid version) smells just like the typical scent that one gets when one goes in a Lush shop.
I wish I'd get the herbal scent that some reviewers wrote here but all I get is a soapy, powdery something. It somewhat reminds me of a weaker Smuggler's Soul (which I can not stand as well) so I thought there must be sandalwood in the composition but it doesn't.

I like it! I tried it in store, was gonna purchase Rose Jam but the SA recommended it to me. Got home and tested it out and I regretted purchasing it. The opening is very hebal...? Strong one. I sprayed it on my clothes the next day, still hated the opening. But after a few hours, it's very lovely. My boyfriend likes it too.

-Opens with a herbal blend of notes.
-As with most Lush perfumes, this is a largely linear scent.
-Morphs into a powdery, floral indistinct mess when it gets to the middle notes.
-Not fbw. (-)

This has a very "vintage vibe" and I like it! It's very UN-LUSH-like while still remaining Soapy & edible ! The dry-down is very cozy and warm. Surprised this was not called "Grandmother's Hugs". Still remains unisex and almost smells like something from another house -- like Bond No. 9 . Yeah ..the dry-down is like "I want all my clothes to smell like this all the time". Sample it !

Smooth, musky, a pinch fruity and green. This is great. It’s quite a departure from the usual Lush powdery, sweet, bath bomb experience. This could be from a different house all together. When looking at the notes gallbanum and Rosemary I was expecting something ultra green but it’s not really. It’s actually quiet and white musky. It’s a bit masculine I’d say. It’s very, very pleasant and warm.

First Impression: The Olive Branch is my favourite Lush scent. Why they had to ruin it with Blackberry I don't know. Annoying

Dry down: This is gorgeous. It's The Olive Branch with a richness. Musky and rich, suitable for all ages. VERY sexy.

A girl friend of mine was wearing this and I felt the need to ask what fragrance it was. Then I went to purchase it thinking I could always resell it or gift it. Little did I know I was going to keep it for myself. Pansy is a bit too feminine for men to wear confidently so I use it as a pillow/stay-at-home scent. It's so smooth, warm, comforting... Also kind of unique! The blackberry note is the most noticeable to me but not the most dominant if that makes sense, it sticks out (sharp, watery quality) like a top note that doesn't budge away even an hour post spray. The rest is sweet, warm, enveloping, cozy.

Definitely worth a try, Pansy has one of the best price/quality ratio
among the fragrances I own.
Le printemps dans une bouteille !
I love this perfume, it is soft, warming and it makes me feel calm but floral fruity absolutely no not on me.

Comforting. Gentle.
End note has a mature texture. I smell little bit of vanilla,too. Honestly think this is one of the most pleasant end note, which managed to perfectly sip into my skin scent.
I would say that this scent is rather plain. It really doesn't have the distinguishable identity. Not that complexity to anticipate..To praise in other way, predictable.
Yet I think this obviousness makes people to feel safe. This is a scent of floral harmony where I'm sure that this is generally appealing and nobody would be offended by this.
Good for everyday use, but a bit pricey for a student like me.

Warm, smoky, cuddly. It doesn't follow me or envelop me in a billowing perfume cloud, but rather a tight warm embrace. To me this is a perfect autumn/winter fragrance when I crave a bit of warmth but not the loud heat of summer just yet!

Lately, I have learned that American Cream is available in perfume version in my region and I was rushing to try it in a Lush store. I tested American Cream and what I detected was a non rich nor creamy version of slight vegetal herbal vanilla with a trail of antiseptic scent along with it, maybe that was a bad batch and it was nothing like the hair conditioner.

With several Lush newly available perfumes in store in my region and have been under my radar: Imogen Rose, Two More Hearts and Cocktail, my nose was too busy to allow each giving me a clear impression. They all seem quite wearable and likeable. Imogen Rose has some middle eastern rosy vibe going on, but relatively lightweight... Cocktail is refreshing green and summery, Two More Hearts has a toned down Ylang Ylang along with some white florals that’s not too heady.... only 100ml for these were available, probably were not what I would consider to purchase... I have tested Breath of God many many times, it’s nice and quite unique, but for some reason it never becomes something that’s so captivating and a full bottle worthy to me... however, Pansy stood out from this bunch, the opening is all about lime and blackberry... refreshing, tart, green, citrusy.... after it settles down... A faint powdery floral... something green but I’m unable to identify if it’s rosemary or not... Overall it’s quite well blended, reminds me of a little bit of fizzy pop soda, happy and summery. I can relate to how it was a scent for a shower gel from the dry down.

I found it quite challenging to test perfumes in Lush Store, might give it another try next time.

Actually Pansy was the original perfume of Cosmetics to Go before they became Lush. :) The Olive Branch shower gel was inspired by Pansy perfume. Pansy is more floral green and The Olive Branch (Lush kitchen perfume / body spray) is more musky citrusy even though they share the main ingredients/notes. Personally I prefer Pansy (2019, I haven't smelled the original 1993 version).

This is the fragrance 'The Olive Branch' which has been renamed.

The same scent as the shower gel.

An atmospheric joy!

Lillies almost too far gone and a touch of formaldehyde. Lily dominant frags are a rarity in this era and I am here to appreciate this with all my vintage lily loving heart. This is a gothic beauty and forever in my top ten. Rich.
This is a beautiful, powdery white lily however I don’t get any death or decay from this. It’s very clean and somber, yet I feel like it’s missing something.

when i worked at lush 2015-2017 i got to try this firsthand at a conference before its release. it was created after the owner’s father died.
he wanted to recreate all feeling of all the flowers his family received. they really definitley gives off funeral home vibes but dries down to a basic white floral!

In all my years of buying fragrances, this is the only blind buy I kinda regret. I found out about it from a YouTuber and bought it thinking it would be a moody dramatic gothic fragrance like Dior's Midnight Poison. I wanted to like it, I really did. And objectively it's not a bad scent at all. But, true to its name, it does evoke feelings of sadness and (like a few other comments mentioned) smells like a funeral home... which is probably the point. Anyway, I don't exactly hate it, but it's a pass from me.

The dry down was completely different from the first spray. It starts off smelling like pure rot and decay and it transforms into a beautiful white floral. It’s a unique scent that changes throughout the day..perfect for those with a morbid curiosity.
A Gothic powdery white floral scent that is surprisingly wearable. It's ok, quite dark. Reminds me of Black Datura for some reason

Sniffed it and I got a big frown on my face. Something about this makes me sad which is the point. Not a fan. Very thick with the florals (Lily? I'm not strong enough to identify what I smell in this but it's certainly not jasmine or gardenia!) in a way which I don't like, but that's the point of this perfume so I can't really say the perfume failed in this regard. Maybe if it toned down the lilies I would enjoy it, I want to peek behind the curtain of this a bit more some day. Maybe I will sniff again.

Edit: Let me save you the trouble. If you've ever smelled Tubereuse Criminelle by Serge Lutens, then this is just Lush's version of it. But more grim, darker, and thicker on the white florals. I don't like it but I like Tubereuse Criminelle, because it's all these things in moderation.

i love layering this with grass from lush whenever I stop in. The two together is such an ideal summer scent. Lily, indolic, but covered in pollen, and uplifted by the grassy sunny notes, complex but they have the same DNA.

So lovely and unique! Kind of indolic, not in a seductive way, more in a "funeral flowers" type of way.
I personally would never have guessed it was basically a lily soliflore tho. Smells like Ylang Ylang mixed with some lily, but mostly Ylang Ylang.
I'll have to investigate the official pyramid, cause it surely contains a lot of it, and I love it.

A nice scent, but as a funerary archaeologist I was looking for something a bit more...realistic, more like thousand year old bones and the *actual* cloying smell of decay so advanced it just smells more like a forest than anything else. I expected notes of petrichor and a more forward animalic scent, but instead it's overwhelmingly floral. It's still a beautiful scent but not what I was expecting. I see the vision of funeral bouquet and respect it though.

i just went through the list of cons on this scent and i'm going to have to hard disagree with some of them.

i think the strong indolic nature of this scent and the overpowering lily note is what truly makes the name of this fragrance so apt. some may liken it to Funeral Home by Demeter, and while i've not smelt it i'm ready to disagree.

i first smelt this on a mid-afternoon in autumn, and i immediately saw an image in my mind's eye. (**let me preface this by saying that i'm not much of a daydreamer or an imaginer, so when i do receive some kind of imagery from a fragrance, i'll usually purchase it. that to me is a sign that the scent speaks to me.**)

this smells exactly like a British park after autumn rain in the late afternoon or early evening, when it's starting to get dark. this is when the trees are starting to shed their leaves and become bare, and the litter is slowly beginning to break down and decompose. i get the scent of wet leaf litter, the slightest hint of that raw/ animalic(??) vibe from rotting plants, but also the sweet smell of decay that is often associated with decomposition. i'd say it's fairly melancholy because it clearly smells like something to do with death, yet it is beautiful to me in the way it is serene and comforting. it's definitely more outdoorsy than a funeral home. another possible comparison if we're going along the lines of funerals is a columbarium by the mountains.

i think this is a palatable and wearable gothic scent for the lovers of all things dark and mellow. while Death and Decay itself isn't the darkest, heaviest scent out there, it's a fragrance that evoked a strange sort of peace and bittersweetness in me when i first smelt it. i've rarely liked a fragrance so much on the first sniff and i'm not even exaggerating LOL. i don't find it overpowering despite my usual aversion to many white flower forward fragrances (i have a vendetta against jasmine LOL), and i'd argue that the lilies in this perfume are quite delicate and almost intoxicating. on that note, i will say i don't get much powderiness from this fragrance.

one last note: i have an old leather handbag that i thrifted and didn't bother deodourising because i'm a sucker for strange smells and quite like the animalic, smoky and slightly sweet notes i get from the smell of the old leather. i often wear that bag when i wear this fragrance to add more of an animalic feel to my overall scent profile for the day, and really play into the mournful, funereal feel of Death and Decay.

Does not smell like funeral home, maybe like a cemetery though. I was mainly looking for lily but I get a bunch of mixed florals, perhaps chrysanthemun among them, but lily did not stand out. Performance is fine.

It's a very pretty, powdery floral fragrance. While Fragrantica lists lily and the creator notes mention it, on the Lush website, lily is not mentioned anywhere. They list Jasmine, Rose, Ylang-ylang and Tonka..NO lily. Strange, right?
