With the florals, it has this warm presence in the drydown which adds interest and keeps it from being boring. I really like this, in spite of the name. Rather femme leaning.
Ok performance, does better on clothes.

BUT LET'S BE CLEAR - there is
Nothing funeral.
Nothing about death.
Or decay.
Or a coffin.
Or a vampire.
No gut wrenching goodbyes or grief acceptance or cold stone mausoleum floors...what the heck??..LOL(THAT made me laugh A LOT, such imagination!.., 😁)

IT'S A PERFUME, lol...with some rather strange & interesting MARKETING. Lush does that- all the time.

It's not goth, or dark ...
It's a softly spicy, floral fragrance.
It smells like THE BEST hotel soap in the world. I plan on buying a bottle.
I JUST HOPE no one asks what I'm wearing because THAT would be embarrassing.😄

Smells like a funeral home- and you either love it, or hate it! Personally, I love it. Death and decay was my signature for years- flowery and a little dusty, a little old. Forgotten flower petals in a used bookshop. Unfortunately, like many Lush scents it doesn't last very long (absolutely not worth it in a solid perfume, it fades in like an hour). But that's it's only failure.

i tried this perfume, coaxed by the name and it being around halloween, but for some reason on my skin all i could smell was a floral diaper cream and an almost cat-piss-at-grandma's-house scent? nothing like decay, just like a funeral home overcrowded with lilies. i suppose it fulfills the death part if you're talking about that.

It's been my favorite for years. It smells like old people's soap and funeral home to me, with heavy floral notes and a bit of a dusty aspect that reminds me of pachouli incense. My roommate thinks it makes me smell like an old lady, but i like it that way.
This smells like the breath of someone who got really drunk and was then given a cup of strong jasmine tea in hopes it would mitigate their hangover. It did not.

I have only used the solid version. Death and Decay is my favorite fragrance of all time - it's strong, floral, slightly powdery and peppery, dark, brooding, gothic. For me it's not quite giving funeral. It's walking past almost nauseatingly strong blooming flowers on a hot, humid late summer night. Flower bouquets on the bedside, quiet, still air, hot feverish skin as the inevitable approaches. There's a sense of doom, like knowing something bad is coming but accepting it and choosing to take it in with all senses since you can't avoid it.

D&D is my signature scent and I only apply it on special occasions, as it's no longer available as solid and the liquid is for sale three countries away from me. I keep searching for something, anything that will scratch the same dark, gothic floral itch so I can move on from D&D but I've not smelled anything like it anywhere in any form. It's bewitched me.

I'd say it feminine-leaning unisex, I myself am a goth man and it makes me feel powerful and confident.

It smells like embalming fluid. Very synthetic and chemical with a floral cover up. There is an element of that spit/ skin smell that comes with lily and lilac, which is new for me. Kind of a different take on a funerary scent, it’s interesting to compare with Demeter’s Funeral Home which is much cleaner but equally plasticky. Plasticky works in both these cases, especially considering the ways we use glamour and artifice to avoid facing the reality of death (at least in north america and western european traditions).
Perfect for late winter, but i get the sense it will be overpoweringly cloying in warm weather.

This is a lovely scent that I don't really think I need given the price point.

This is a lily Soliflore that does smell great for what it is. It smells like waxy, wet lilies with a slightly smell of Nivea Creme going on.

It's indolic and a little spicy as lily tends to be and generally smells quite pleasant if you're a lily fan like I am.

So why do I not want this lovely scent?

Simply put, Anais Anais offers a delightful Lily scent that is much more complex at a far better price whilst offering a similar "funeral parlor" feeling. Between that scent's oakmoss and the delicate powder of hyacinths that undercuts the lilies I just can't in good faith purchase Death and Decay at the steep £100 price when Anais Anais is £32 on the worst day. Even vintage bottles are cheaper!

Also, Viktor and Rolf Tiger Lily offers a more upbeat lily scent for the days when I want a bit more pep in my lily scent.

In conclusion, very nice scent but it lacks the complexity to be worth the price for me.

Try Anais Anais if you like this though. You may very well join me in the floral bliss.

Death and Decay is a beautiful, gut wrenching goodbye. I expected Death and Decay to be dark and gothic, something dramatic and moody. Instead, I was hit with the quiet reality of death itself. This isn’t the scent of romanticised decay, it’s the air inside a chapel during a funeral. The overwhelming presence of lilies, their fragile beauty arranged in honour of someone who is no longer there. A perfume of grief, of remembrance, of love that lingers even in loss.

To me, this smells exactly how I imagine the ending of Robert Eggers’ Nosferatu would. A chilling finality, the beauty of death intertwined with sorrow. It embodies the Death and the Maiden motif; delicate florals against the shadow of something inevitable, the contrast between innocence and the inescapable embrace of the unknown.

The white florals are strong, almost too much at first, just like the emotions they represent. The lilies feel waxy, almost suffocating, the way funeral flowers can be when they fill a room. There’s a slight freshness, like the chill of stone floors. It’s haunting, not in a ghostly way, but in how it reminds you of moments you wish you could forget, yet hold onto all the same.

Death and Decay is heartbreakingly beautiful. It doesn’t romanticise grief; it captures the aching truth of it. The kind of scent that stays with you, long after everything else has faded.

I thought this would be a great unique fragrance for a gothy, cemetery vibe but there is a very sharp and cloying urine/ ammonia like smell upon first spray all the way until dry down where it mellows out that I just cannot stand, the dry down smells like one of those fancy old soaps your grandma has that she’s never taken out of the wrapping because it looks good as decoration. Overall for matching description I’d say it’s a 5/10 definitely smells like a funeral but like cat pee as well lol

Lo compré justo estando un poco resfriada, me gustó pero después me empezó a dar alergia y cada vez que me aplicaba solo podía estornudar, además alguien dijo que olía a cementerio 😔 se entiende que muy floral pero la verdad es que es demasiado floral y es demasiado caro para lo que dura :(
As a man this hit me like a blast from my childhood, special beauty soaps in a dish NOT to be used, just for show. I got a bottle and wallow in nostalgia, one of the best from the range.

I absolutely love this perfume. My go-to turned from Vegan Leather Jacket to Death and Decay when I began working at lush. I wanted a gothic, light smell compared to the smokey perfume I was currently wearing. Death and Decay is just that. A goths dream. It smells like lilys, planning a funeral and choosing the flowers for the coffin. It smells like your Nans house in spring and the grief that comes with remembering it.

I often also layer it with VLJ and the combination of the two leaves you smelling like a smoker at a rainy funeral, trying not to cry while a wet black blazer weighs you down. It’s grief and warmth and never feeling whole.

Death and Decay may be my all time favourite fragrance, I think it is beautiful.

Used to love this but something shifted. One day it turned toilet freshener on me and its too sharp. The initial second smells like a real lily and then it becomes a sharp heavy mess. I also seem to be allergic to something in it since it burns my skin… the downside of using natural extracts
Elegant, classy and extremely morbid smelling.
very pretty, simple straightforward white floral and almondy-tonka, cuddly elegant body lotion smell

Out of all of the floral lush scents, this stands out most to me. I would totally rock this as a guy, but that doesn’t mean it’s unisex. I also love the concept of this; Mark Constantine is a genius when it comes to making a story for his scents. If you don’t know, this is a scent which is meant to replicate the scent of the bouquets of lilies which Mark received from family and friends following the death of his father.

There is a strong, sharp, powdery pepper note that I don't think enough people are picking up on, and when I spray it on my neck, I sneeze almost every time. It's a very polarizing scent, and the lilies are dominant. My aunt said it felt like a funeral parlor. But to me, it smells like the Church hall on Pascha-- a little incence-ey. I get a lot of compliments on it, though and its projection is just over arms-length and leaves a very faint trail. More compliments on it from men than from women. A lot of men think it smells gourmand, specifically cinnamon, specifically specifically, "like a cookie".
Beautiful powdery white floral that radiates.

Interesting. The scent changes everyday. It does remind me of my childhood when I found a dead little bird in my garden. It was so beautiful I placed it in an empty cream jar. Too young and innocent to know it would decay soon. How strange the scent but the beauty of the little bird remained.... death inbetween beautiful white flowers. Beautiful decay on your skin, lilys on your clothes.
Then again lilys is strangely not listed on the lush website. Only ylang ylang, Tonka bean, rose and Jasmine. Yet it does smell like lilys.

Perfectly named. Smells like a glowing white bouquet being transported from the funeral home to the cemetery on a cloudy day. Pure floral, tinted with the sweet, powdery smell of cosmetics on cold skin. Smells like the song "Green Velvet" by The Shroud.

Lush chose the most perfect name for this fragrance! A captivating lily scent that is so realistic, very much decaying. Seriously, there's a hint of something dying in this, like a corpse holding a fresh bouquet. Just a sprinkle of sweetness of rotting flesh, pardon for gruesome description. A little off-putting, maybe even gross to some people, but I'm intrigued. I think I'd love to get a bottle, but this is not an easy scent to pull off.

rip ethel cain you would’ve loved this.
a very grounded, realistic Lily scent, the kind you would smell in a funeral home. so simple yet so gorgeous 🤍

This pissed me off ….
Lily of the valley =/= Lily!!!!
Huge difference actually ….

This smells like lilac to me, except real lilac is fleeting and ephemeral, while this is persistent and heady and just a little bit intoxicating. I can definitely envision a funeral home flower arrangement when I wear this if I really try, but the first thing I think of is honestly a lush spring garden full of blooming lilac bushes laden with quivering butterflies. I don't get any hints of rot.

High vibrations in this scent, uplifting, crystalline and bright. I only get lilies and ylang, but blended to a singular, sharp, soapy, and medicinal effect.

Because of the simplicity it blends well with other scents to brighten them. Particularly true with woodier and muskier things to get a lighter, more joyful and less labored feeling.

I like it in the heat, it takes on a hint of fresh plastic pool floaties and copper tone sunscreen.

Eternal floral bomb with spice and powder notes providing grounding. Bought this while abroad in Belgium and was fortunate to have got it in its oil form; the bottle cost me over $100usd at the time but it lasted me nearly ten years with scarce use and its memory still sticks with me. Definitely a morbid scent, as the memories this may evoke in some would be undesirable to say the least, but for those who are looking for a darker aesthetic and going for a vibe that is strange and unusual-I would highly recommend it

Dried lilies, jasmine in a glass casket and the smell still come through but it's muted
I imagined Zhongli would probably wear something like this
Pretty much just straight up Lily all the way through but its lovely and pretty photorealistic. Does indeed smell like a funeral home.

I have an old dropper bottle of this from back when I worked at lush and a kind coworker grabbed this and All Good Things for me from the UK. I have to vehemently disagree with the review highlights saying it doesn’t smell like death and decay. It absolutely does, but the beautiful aspects of those vague ideas. It smells like funeral flowers. Like they’ve been sitting in water for a little too long and are at that point where you can tell they’re on their last leg but you’re not ready to toss them yet. It smells melancholy if that makes sense but it’s really beautiful. I love jasmine but I usually stay away from powdery fragrances. However, this isn’t baby powder like I usually hate. It’s like… your mom’s old make up she let you play with. There are a lot of things about this perfume that conjure feelings of nostalgia and longing for what used to be but in a loving way, not a sad way. Like “look at this beautiful journey I’ve been on that shaped me into who I am today. Full of heartache and happiness, somehow I’ve ended up here”. And that’s the Death and Decay that gives it its name.

I think I might be in love...the first spray is pure, intoxicating lily. It's so floral and yet not feminine at all; it feels subdued, comforting, a little ghostly. This is what the beautiful, mysterious girl standing in the corner at the party is wearing. The scent is fairly linear but does become softer and creamier with time. To my nose there's no pepper at all. I think I'm going to be sneaking into and out of the sample section in Lush for a while.
If yankee candle made a Funeral Home scent.

I had bought a tin of this when it first came out, I think it was when my city got Lush. I lost it not long after…so annoying. fast forward, just found it a few weeks ago, safely packed up in a forgotten box stored in a cool dry cellar…I feel like I won a prize! And wow it aged so well. Deepened. Smoooooth. I live on the North Atlantic ocean, and this I layered with Lush Lust solid. They sing together in ocean fog. Great longevity and the scent stays true, softly fading but never fully leaving. It’s too bad Death&Decay isn’t available as a solid anymore, it really is the cleanest & highest quality solid I’ve tried…maybe a limited run? Anniversary promotion perhaps?
(psst…Lush… ;)

This opens with heady creamy lush of every white flowers, but the headiness, it doesn't last. Try breathing for a while, as to get new vitality from the pepper, but unfortunately drowns and dies in the dark water of modesty and oblivion...Sad, like death and decay is.

I‘ve been a huge fan of Lush perfumes for 7 years now but I didn‘t get to try this perfume till now. I guess I kept distance from floral scents for some reason for too long and most of the Lush perfumes I haven‘t tried are florals, I‘m a guy and I don‘t like wearing heavy powdery florals. I got this perfume a few days ago in Prague and I gotta say it surprised me a lot.
At first it smells really fresh. Almost like a garden in the summer after it‘s rained at night. A little bit like some flowers that have been in a vase for a day or two and you smell that floral aroma mixed with watery notes. It‘s very clean and fresh. The top notes remind me of Lust but it‘s not as in your face and heady as Lust. I guess it‘s the combination of rose, jasmine and ylang ylang that both of these perfumes have. Chances are, if you enjoy one of them, you‘re probably enjoy the other. I had Lust 6 years ago and I loved it at first but I had to sell it later on because it was just too strong for me. Death and Decay is lighter but not weak. You also get some tonka bean notes in the background. After some time, the scent becomes a little bit more powdery (but not in a grandma type of way) and soapy (again not in a bad way, it just smells clean and fresh) and you‘re left with a delicate floral aroma that definitely screams LUSH and is unisex.
I put this perfume on around 10:30 am and now it‘s 11:30 pm. I can still smell it on my wrist (of course it‘s not as strong as when I sprayed it earlier today, but the scent is there) and I did a lot of physical activity during this hot summer day (I went cycling for an hour and took 15 k steps). This perfume lasts and is high quality. The price is high but its performance is outstanding. I definitely recommend buying this perfume if you enjoy the scent.

Very nice upon first spray - I actually got a lot of jasmine, a bit reminiscent of their Lust scent. Smelled kind of dusty in a way that I liked upon opening. But the dry down was pure baby powder, which I’m less into. In the end it was a pass for me.

My dearest Death and Decay, what can I say! Another heavy-hitter from Lush. Purposefully lethargic, numb, indifferent. Complex and subjective. Hypnotically off-putting. Vampiress whispering to her soon-to-be victim, "come into my boudoir."

Bountiful white lilies compete with other white florals: roses, ylang-ylang, jasmine, some of them fresh, but many withered with age, giving us a foreign sense of floral musk, the Decay. Mortician's cosmetic powder dusted liberally onto the corpse, illusions of cleanliness trying to mask the heart beneath: the Death, something damp, indole (the semi-sweet, dirty, rot kind), cream with no sweetness, wax, and cloves. The girlies who've roamed cemeteries during significant downpours or happened upon a shallow, poorly concealed grave would get it—the girls that don't get it, simply don't!

If you don't care for the morbid or occult themes, if the name on the bottle unsettles you, if you only like your florals smelling fresh and vibrant, if you mainly enjoy upbeat and peppy, if you hate cloudy days, if you enjoy basic, this is not the fragrance for you.

Smells like Bauhaus - Bela Lugosi's Dead:
"The virginal brides file past his tomb
Strewn with time's dead flowers
Bereft in deathly bloom
Alone in a darkened room
The Count
Bela Lugosi's dead..."

Same potent and long-lasting Lush formula. Good for intimate settings (used in moderation, of course)—funerals or office settings alike. I have this in both the spray and solid, I find the solid has more of the creamy and spicy notes shining through. A gentle scent that does not command head-turns like most other perfumes, but instead suggests you to sniff till you are content. This got me the compliment "you smell very comforting, cozy," if only I could describe how their face twisted with confusion when I replied "Thank you! I'm wearing Death and Decay by Lush."

This fragrance has had a haunting influence over me. Shivers up my spine after application, I am commanded to do my eyeshadow and eyeliner heavier, darker, my lips done with burgundy, deep browns, and black; I trail to my wardrobe and dawn only black or muted deep colors for the day, silver accessories. I am imbued with something gothic, something Victorian—I become a muse of Dark Romanticism.

Entranced and soothed with Death and Decay's namesake reminder of the inevitable fate we face as mortal beings. And this fragrance has allowed me to make peace with it.

Strong lily scent. This scent is evocative of the scent of potent, spicey spring flower bulbs - like hyacinth, narcissus and Easter lilies. Not in a fresh, green way - but in a rich, thick, indolic way. It also reminds me of black locust flowers.

It goes on a bit strong at first, a bit sharp and slightly mothbally. But luckily that aspect fades fast and the scent smoothes out. It remains a lily scent thoughout the wear - but by the drydown it becomes much softer, soapier.

I think this is a perfect spring scent (when it is still cool out) because as I said it reminds me of heady/spicey spring flower bulbs. It would also be nice for fall tho, because it is floral, but it is rich enough for autumn season. This scent is too heavy for summer imo and it goes a bit sour in the heat.

Lovely lily bouquet with some intoxicating spice mixed in. I really enjoy this fragrance. I feel very sexy and mysterious when I wear this. It is definitely more linear than some of Lush's scents but it's still a fragrance I enjoy a lot.
Smells putrid and offensive and the price is laughable.

As someone who's mother's favourite flower is white lily, I was expecting a 'rich floral bouquet' or 'decaying floral bouquet' as described by at least half the reviewers here... But all I got was burnt plastic and used public toilet from FIRST SPRAY.

Seriously, this is just as pungent as faecal oud - downright offensive in most environments. This is far from sophisticated and elegant... Nor is it complex or ''unique'' - it's burnt plastic / public toilet from first spray to dry-down.
What really peeves me is this costs $125, Lush is really pushing prices higher than well-known niche brands.
The only upside (or downside in this case) is that this is very strong and long lasting compared to other Lush scents.

Not impressed, there are far more interesting scents from Lush. 'Death and Decay' is very aptly named through - I'm sure something died and has started to decay inside my body ever since I sniffed this.

After reading the reviews, the name of the bottle, the notes, and the vibe, I was extremely excited to try this, as someone who spends a lot of time in cemeteries. The smell of the cemetery is something which I find to be the most beautiful smell to exist. Sweet, freshly-cut grass, earth, blooming lilies and decaying flowers. What did I smell when I tried this? A service station toilet. Seriously. Like, the smell of a toilet that is regularly used which hasn’t been cleaned all day, mixed with a cheap, powdery foam soap. Now I’m all for dirty fragrances, but this just smells straight up disgusting. If you want to smell like a motorway toilet, this would be perfect for you!

Smells like a massive, ripe, fully-bloomed funerary bouquet of white lilies. Nothing much beyond that, maybe a slight additional green-woodsy pang, but the central note is so rich and well-defined that it's hard to be upset with it. Layers exquisitely with any other clean scent and adds dimension and sweetness without being cloying or sugary.

Heady and elegant. A wilting bouquet of intoxicating jasmine, white roses and lilies, with powdery pollen and cinnamon incense. Melancholic and beautiful. Not my favourite from Lush, though it's a strong like.

The fragrance notes should also list jasmine, ylang ylang, rose and tonka bean.

Got my hands on the vintage formulation this week. The one in the dropper bottle. Never been opened so the scent is entirely intact. I must say, for those who wonder: to my surprise, the reformulation of this scent is pretty much the same. Bravo lush!

Its a heady floral, lily to be exact. But its the smell of lily's in decay. This makes me feel nostalgic but i don't know why. The very first time i sniffed this, i was in store and i was a bit overwhelmed by it. Its the feeling you get when you've unlocked a scent memory, only there is no memory? It made me feel a tad bit nervous like something was about to happen but i wasn't sure if it was scary or exciting, maybe it was both? I felt so moved by this i thought it was a little silly at first. The current version is slightly more powdery then the vintage version (wich is the one i am wearing right now) the vintage version is just slllliiightly more syrupy. And maybe I'm mistaking but i feel like the current version is a bit stronger maybe? Projects more maybe? I'm not sure about that though. I just remember when i used up a tester vial of that one, the smell stuck in my house for weeks. It was on everything i had touched when wearing it. I feel like the vintage one i am wearing is just a tad closer to the skin, but i only just started wearing it so maybe it's too early to tell. Anyway. If you are into let's say, Bpal perfumes, you will 100% like/love this one. I am still going to buy the 100 ml as well as i don't think I'll ever want to run out. :)

white flowers with hints of powder and spice that almost remind me of incense. very true to name, smells like a church holding a beautiful and elaborate funeral service. rich but not cloying or overwhelming. i got this as a gift from a sweet coworker and i really could not be happier this might be my new favorite perfume

-Smells like a clean baby.
-More specifically, one which has had some baby powder smeared all over its diapered bottom.
-Linear scent to my nose. (-)

Lou Reed’s mistress’s balled-up tissue. Diaphanous organza dresses making way for a spider’s web. Defenestrated polyisoprene dipped in a lipstick sugar kiss. Sanguine cabbage served on a bed of frostbitten Flixotide. One thesaurus borne of a single mind and spread over two reviews, destined to fight itself in a masked ballroom. The ouroboros. A dog eating its own vomit.

A semi plastic lily interspersed with wafts of supermarket mushrooms. I find this strangely balmy with a morning breath indole. Mildewy…Occasionally smells like the inside of a pencil case. I am mesmerized by @sarahswitchblade’s review! Inspired by this, I would like to add my own lyrical interpretation of this captivating fragrance.

“Losing him was blue like I'd never known
Missing him was dark gray, all alone (woah)
Forgetting him was like
Trying to know somebody you never met
But loving him was red”
Red (Taylor’s Version) [From the Vault]

rotting lilies weeping in a sunken garden. fog gathering on glistening grass outside an abandoned church. pale hands pulling flowers out of the earth, trailing with wet soil. stretching supinely with hands turned up. dearly departed, decaying by a creek.

a period of statis. lush perianths dance in spectral air, a tender song of indolic jasmine lulls. the writing on the wall meets hushed voices of solemnity. formaldehyde and dust settle onto cold linoleum. a forgotten bouquet of lilies in a hospital room eating oxygen.

wandering of whim, waxing and waning. draping of lace, interment eternal. parting willingly, sweetly, with not an ounce of malignity. a final testament for those who recall such adversities to efface them for the better- to remember me through death and decay.

a dolorous take on indole. so delicate yet tranquilizing. i remember testing this perfume when i first discovered lust 5 years ago. lust was my signature when i was 14, and the fact i still wear it today solidified my belief that i'd now be head over heels for death and decay.

i decided on a whim to blind buy 3.4 oz of it and i could not be happier in my decision! it's so keen to me. i find it beyond comforting, it's a very touching scent. so mournful and poetic and beyond words.

(some lyrics from one of my favorite songs that happen to coincide)

"Two pale figures ache in silence
Timeless in the quiet ground
Side by side in age and sadness

I watched and acted wordlessly
As piece by piece you performed your story
Moving through an unknown past
Dancing at the funeral party’
what I was looking for. gloomy lily on the edge of the rotten, funereal, cemetery. maybe it lacks a bit of performance. but it's perfect. 9.5 / 10

I tried this on at lush and immediately thought oh jeez funerals and Halitosis. I kept getting whiffs of it in the air as I was walking turning very pleasant with some sweet Ylang Ylang along side the dominant lily and Jasmine, the Jasmine and Lily died down some and it became very well blended, then it got soapy, and then later on I got cinnamon. Final dry down was sweet white floral. I would love to have a bottle for myself.

The name is meant to mislead you. The nose behind this fragrance wanted to create something "surprisingly pleasant when you're expecting something awful". If you smelled this I think you'll agree that's exactly what he managed to do.

This is honestly not only one of Lush's best but one of the best perfumes I've ever smelled, hands down. I think this perfume is a work of genius. The way that it evolves is so interesting to me. It's one of those rare ones where I love it for every single second of its life. It's a floral through and through but changes so much more than you would expect. The opening is like a fizzy, bubbling, fermenting floral bouquet from which the jasmine distinguishes itself more and more as it progresses into the core. During that time when the jasmine is at the forefront, it's really similar to Lush's Lust (basically pure jasmine). If you aren't familiar with the way Lush does jasmine, it's like chemical and plastic yet addictive and intoxicating.

As the jasmine dies down, it turns into such a beautiful, delicate white floral. That's what you're left with except as it dries down, it turns creamier and creamier and the end result is so comforting. The drydown is really similar to Lush's Ghost (or Lush's Sultana of Soap in terms of creaminess). I only picked up a bottle this summer so I didn't get a chance to smell it in cold weather yet but so far, I've found that I like it much more on humid days. It projects well, it has decent staying power, it was recently made more expensive but it's worth the price.

(This review is for the version they came out with for the black label perfumes they only sell in big bottles, I've heard that this is slightly different from older versions in that it's more soapy but it's the only version I've ever tried so I wouldn't know.)

This is my funeral scent. I know it sounds a bit morbid, but it has been very therapeutic actually. Now, when I put it on I'm instantly put in a serene and somber mood. It helpes me realise what is going on. I put it on when I moved out of my moms house and when we put the family dog down. It has besome my scent for goodbyes. Its bittersweet and comforting at the same time. The image I get when I put it on is sitting in the pews at church, everyone in their own little world of grief. Notes playing on the organ, the sound of crying. I look up at the casket, flowers laid on top, an the sun falls through tall church windows. I realise this is as much a beginning as an ending. I genuinly love this scent.

Death and Decay is a mass of white lilies, an elaborate wreath, a store-bought bouquet, funeral arrangement or perhaps all of these incarnations of this melancholic meditative floral. These blooms are at the height of their beauty; their alabaster form and curve full and flourishing, just on the cusp of decay. This is a narcotic white floral fragrance heavy with every aspect it evokes-- from the sweet waxy petals, to the subtle spice of pollen, to the pearlescent plastic wrapped around the stems.

for me this is my number one ultimate fragrance of all time. it pulls as a really warm and spicy intoxicating white floral but not incensey in the slightest. if i could drown myself in this everyday i would.

I got this as I am a huge lover of lily and jasmine. Death and Decay is a great name for this. It is like dying lilies, when they are starting to decay, pollen everywhere, petals curling up. With an interesting, plastic note in the beginning that fades a little over time. Indolic, yes, but more in a decaying way. It feels a bit incomplete, as in another layer would complete this scent - I am going to test layering this with other perfumes. In a rather morbid way, my parcel got delayed in the post and it arrived in the morning of my father’s passing. Couldn’t be more appropriate. I will always remember this scent.
very funeral and penetrating, but after a while it gives me a headache and becomes a scent of soap.

This is one of my favorite fragrances (as previously reviewed below) but it was only available for a limited time!

Well, I just found that LUSH have brought it back!
However, I'm quite sure that the ingredients are different. I have read previously that they have been adding water to scents which previously contained none, thus making their scents far weaker.
It's also pretty pricey, coming in at £95 for 100ml, so if it is weaker that's not so grand. Good to see a bigger size being made available though!

Looking forward to trying it and finding out if it's anything like the original version - which I own in the solid variant and the dropper/splash bottle variant.

Heads up to fans of DEATH & DECAY -
IT'S BAAAAAACK!

I used to own this one. I love white flowers and lily is one of them. I also love the name to bits. That's where my love ends. The floral notes are interesting, heavy, dry and a bit stale, there is also a bit of light greenery to bring some levity. My problem comes with the introduction of the tonka, that creates a smell that reminds me quite a bit of acetone. I feel like it clashes, dries down aggressive and could do with some more sweetness. But who knows, that might just be my sugar addiction talking.

Beautiful and complex. A thick soapy and slightly cloying (which adds to it's charm) fragrance.

The overwhelming smell of Lily in this is from Lilial which is a synthetic aldehyde used in Laundry powders. This is backed up with cinnamyl alcohol (natural or chemical based) which is also powdery, and has notes of hyacinth. Combined they create quite a punch.
The natural fragrances sit underneath these and I find them difficult to detect as the synthetics remain constant and very loud (which I assume is the intention).

The only way I have been able to unravel Death and Decay is to use it along side Arlesienne by L'Occitane only then can I pick out the Rose (Damascus) and the Tonka.

After quite some time the synthetics start to calm down but they take the natural oils with them so you never get to the stage where the perfume changes and the notes become readily identifiable.


I love Death and Decay and I'm really sorry that it's been discontinued.

It smells just like lilies! I love lilies so I am totally into it. It is fresh with a little bit of baby powder. It is exactly the kind of scent you smell in funerals when there is a bunch of flower surrounding you. Overall it just reminds me of my family's love her lilies. However, the scent is probably to "old" for me, if that makes any sense.
It smells like public bathrooms, not sure if its an air freshener they use or a toilet cleaner but this smell is very much like it.

I was hoping for indolic and challenging. Death and Decay smells of neither death nor decay but the pearlescent white soap in government bathrooms in the 90s. A positive is that the solid perfume is white/cream so it doesn’t stain your skin or clothes like some of the other pigmented solid scents do.

I am not sure what indole smells like. This did not smell of death or dying flowers to me though. I guess indole is that strange background smell on the initial blast, that quickly turns into fresh cut spring flowers, very green with a hint of rose and tonka (almost marzipan like)in the background. The dry down smells very similar to the Mary Quant perfume in a tin from the 70's or indeed, Lush's own 1000 kisses.

I like it but see it as a summer evening or formal occasion scent. No black goth outfits or sexy siren red, more floral wedding guest attire or slinky pastel number. Different from the norm and quite strong. You will get noticed!!
Absolutely love this perfume - nearly cried when I was told that it had been discontinued. Went to Lush to buy more, and was given the bad news. Tried to find more elsewhere without luck.

Just the sickly sweet corpse-like lily I was looking for. Nice goth gf aesthetic, obscenely strong opening, then mellows out to a bready smell close to a diluted red aoud. Amazing quality for the price. I got the dropper bottle because it's stronger and more complete of a scent than the solid.

I ordered the solid. Wicked lovely concept, but I feel it just didn't hit its mark. I expected angsty, vintage-guitar-playing vampires in lacy cravats or whatever. Maybe if the other notes had played a more balanced role, but this was just overwhelmingly WHITE FLORAL. Obnoxiously so. No complexity. It reminded me of a funeral only in that I wanted to avoid it.

Way back in my tweens I had a bottle of some Yves Rocher number that was made with lilies and something spicy and the dichotomy was actually quite lovely, so I really feel like this one just needs to be reworked because the concept is just too cool to abandon.

....now I need to go figure out which Yves Rocher perfume that was. Dangit.
I have been told by a sales assistant that it is being discontinued... They are selling their last bottles.

I just received the liquid version of this beauty. I loved the solid so much that after spending some time with it, thought it worth the expenditure in hopes for extra projection and strength. And it delivers.

How do the solid and liquid compare? The liquid is not as waxy/soapy from the container. It also has a bit of a boozy vibe to open, not like an inherent base alcohol blast, but like an intentional note of styrax or extra indole. It does settle down into virtually the same vibrant scent (see my first review a few boxes down), but with with more staying power and sillage.

I just wish that the dropper was a spray instead as I like to apply diffusively instead of on a concentrated spot. Easily fixed with a transfer into an empty spray bottle, however this stuff is strong and one drop from the pipette does the trick, so I'll be spraying with caution or diluting with some perfumer's alcohol.

I finally tried this today, worrying it would be too indolic, but I don't find it indolic at all. Lush scents work well with my skin chemistry, I don't get indoles, Lust is actually a compliment getter for me even from perfume haters! :) Anyway, I found this disappointing because it was just soapy and clinical. Nothing dark, gothic, or even sexual. Just hospital bathroom soap. Oh well.

Buxom, thriving, flourishing. Death and Decay is a fully realized, optimistic flower in the height of its beauty; a truly superb operatic aria.

This lily is narcotic and mature, heavily laden with dark orange pollen and reeking with an indolic sap. A little spicy, like a hint of metallic clove accents this beauty. Any fuller and her petals would be falling and her pollen littering the stage with rust; right on the verge of decay.

I am madly in love with this scent. I had sampled a few lilies recently in my quest for the perfect one. And here she is, thanks to a beautiful Fragrantican who gifted this to me.

This is the perfume solid. I see chimidoro's observation below that this is spicier than the liquid perfume, so I'll be sticking to the solid because this scent is perfection. The texture also feels like waxy petals which adds to the experience. I think this lily-bomb will be fantastic for layering too. So pleased, I haven't been so unexpectedly seduced by a fragrance like this for a long time.

I love this scent. I'm talking the liquid version.
I wonder why Fragrantica's note list tells that it has lily, powdery notes and spicy notes, and nothing else. You can go Lush's own page and see that it's listed ylang ylang oil, tonka absolute,rose oil, jasmine absolute, and indole. Also there's lily note ( not lily-of-the-valley) but I don't know if it's natural or not (go and look, maybe you understand better).
This is really really beautiful floral perfume. Im going to add that in my collection as soon as possible.

Edit, February 2018: I never thought that they would discontinue this beauty. Lush changed almost the whole collection, and I never got this. When I went finally to buy this, they said it doesn't exist anymore. I'm so disappointed...

All LUSH PRODUCTS SMELL CHEAP, VERY OBVIOUS AND LITERALLY. IN THE SAME CLIMATE IS " FUNERAL HOME" "BY DEMETER - MUCH BETTER FRAGRANCE.. ANYWAY I UNDERSTAND IDEA BEHIND IT... BUT... COME ON... BE MORE - AT LEAST ONE CLASS HIGHER... EVEN WHEN LUSH COSTUMERS ARE TEENAGERS. TEACH THEM GOOD TASTE...PLEASE..
a different scent. but it smells like rotten cemetery flowers. But I appreciate the aroma diversity.

A gorgeous, delectably soapy, spiced & silken, moist & musky lily.

This scent is in the same vein as The Body Shop's original White Musk oil (which I love), only cooler/crisper/more biting in character, with less notes & boasting a dominant, all-encompassing focus on the lily.
Striking shades of Donna Karan's Gold are also apparent here, but I find that rather sickly sweet, too strong and too dry for my taste.

I smell no lily of the valley here.
(Appreciate & agree with Calvini's review.)

Powdery, but not overly "tonka bean style" dry.
Soapy, though not overtly aldehydic.
Creamy, yet not overly vanillic.

The solid is a touch spicier than the liquid version.
I was actually put in mind of a good korma the first time I smelled the solid. (Please don't let that put you off!)

This is one of those scents that I've often applied before bed. A classic, ladylike scent, I assume is intended for evening wear.
I often find myself opening the bottle to take a sly sniff of the dropper rather than to apply to my skin.

I adore LUSH's Death & Decay & hope it remains available indefinitely. (Though I'm upset by the price hike....)

Skin close, initially with soft to arm's length projection. Subtle but lasting.

At this point you’ll have to admit that the Gorilla perfume house has no difficulties going even anti-marketing when they feel like. Presenting really non-conformist art concepts is already forceful, but look at how easily they’ve launched a product with this sinister name and such an awful smell. Similarly, launching a supposedly dystopian perfume describing it by words such as ’’unnerving, unsettling, disjointed, fractured" and "bitterness’’ (see: The Bug) - doesn’t this all go against marketing as we know it today? Still, these shelves at the shops can be sustained the way they are by the support of all the other popular products that they’re trading (as I figure). Anyways, all I can smell here is a badly scented floor cleaner version of pungent, unpleasant, artificial lily and nothing else. I like, however, the idea that at funerals a lot of lily is used, hence they present a lily perfume with this name.

TLDR: The worst of any Lush perfumes I’ve ever smelt and the biggest rock and roll concept of theirs.

To me this is very nice and natural; it's fresh, clean/soapy & dirty/musky at the same time, and not really sweet (unlike most other well-known lily fragrances). It feels rather serene as opposed to anything rotten, which is the true message of this fragrance: Acceptance and peace with death.

*BTW true lilies and lily of the valleys are actually quite different; they're both monocots but are in different order & family... This is not an interpretation of the latter

Tried a sample. BLEECH!. All I got from this was a cheap, overpowering lily scent. It could have benefited from combining dank earth with a sickly sweet lily and violet scent; if it wanted to convey death. Be bolder with creating a fragrance that represents such finality.

A great lily fragrance. The opening smells just like inflateable plastic lilos lol It settles quickly and then its all about lilies but there is not a lot of powderiness on me. Im not getting much spice but there is some sweetness. Not too much though. Im sure I can detect musk which is stopping the lily from being to screechy. Moderate sillage and lasts for a good few hours. A nice fragrance for a summer evening.

Despite their names, Death and Decay is almost a mirror image of Lush’s Vanillary. While in Vanillary the dominant sweetness of vanilla and tonka is cut by the fresher but still heady scent of white flowers, in Death and Decay the white flowers are rounded out by vanilla and tonka.

Ylang-ylang and jasmine dominate throughout, from the opening to the dry down. Without the name, I’m not sure I’d have caught lily at all, unless the powdery base is lily pollen. Rose makes a cameo appearance in the heart notes, while vanilla and tonka bean add warmth and creaminess.

This scent is noticeably indolic, which is an uneasy combination with the gourmand notes, and goes some way to explaining why Death and Decay is so polarising. A smidge more sweetness and it would turn from slightly overripe to positively rotting.

I don’t associate Death and Decay with serenity, or even solemn funeral flowers. It’s more like a busy flower market at the end of a hot day, when some of the plants are starting to turn, and others have been crushed under foot.

This all sounds rather unpleasant, but in fact I return to Death and Decay again and again. Like a song that grows on you the more you hear it, this scent is intriguing and unusual. It’s another Lush experiment that manages to create an interesting, challenging scent with just a handful of notes – and a successful one in my opinion.

"lily with over-ripe tones of indole"

Basically.... lily (funeral scent) pumping out ripe indole (feces scent) accurately creating death and decay. If white florals work with your skin chemistry this might just be an interesting and soft scent. Very similar to demeter's "funeral" which is an overload of lilies, but with baby powder and hints of rot.

White florals + me = literal death and decay

I'm very negative about this one. To me it smells like dove soap with a hint of pigeon. If I read it back is funny, but really I do smell pigeon with dove soap. I absolutely dislike it. I throw it away. Oh... I also don't like the dropper, I prefer a spray bottle.
I sniffed this at a Lush store and thought it was the most repulsive thing I'd ever smelled! No floral, no powder, just rot...

Very indolic white lilies and jazmine. Reminds me of my beloved Jazmín en Crema by Vizcántar, with its oily, very indolic bottom. Also reminds me of some vintage floral scents by Myrurgia. It's powdery, comforting, soooo vintage and intoxicating. Only for people who appreciate some dirt and indole in their fumes, not a clean, innocent or youthful floral. It goes rather strong at first but does not last long in my skin,only about two or three hours and it becomes a skin scent, like an expensive floral soap. I find this elegant and propper for a spring day, does not smell of funerals to me perhaps for the different cultural background (in my country the funeral flowers are chrysanthemums and carnations while lilies are more liturgical). It has a certain melancholic quality anyway. Love the packaging, sooooo much reminds me of a potion out of Harry Potter books, more so as it's mainly a lily powerhouse. This could have easily been one of Severus Snape's concoctions dedicated to the memory of his beloved Lily Evans. I'm not ashamed to admit I bought it for the Harry Potter connection and the lovely packaging. A bit too expensive, won't repurchase as Jazmín en Crema de Vizcántar and Nebras by Al Rehab satisfy my taste for white florals at a much lower price and last much longer on my skin.

I'm torn about this fragrance. The first hour or so of wear is lovely, overripe lilies with a lot of powder, it smells very vintage without being "old lady"-ish. The overripe lily I feel can be polarizing, the note comes off very sweet and somewhat musky. However, I feel like you need to be careful while applying because this stuff is STRONG. Not only on skin, any fabric this touches will have the smell of Death and Decay for days, and this smell can easily can be overpowering, suffocating, and even nauseating in excess. After a few hours a note begins to appear that, to be blunt, smells like poop. Like, actual poop. When I first smelled this note I had no idea where it was coming from until I realized it was Death and Decay.
TL;DR It smells like a powdery floral at first, then morphs into what can only be put as flowers and poop.
To me this is a perfume a vampire would wear... narcotic and mesmerizing, so evocative!
It smells like Lush figs and leaf soap.
It's dove soap

Okay. This is just me being me, BUT, everytime I apply this from this little dropper applicator, and see the red and green label saying "Death and Decay" - I just get the strongest Harry Potter vibes. This is like the perfume I got from a shady perfumery in Knockturn Alley. This is a poison. This smells like strong white lilies and lily of the valley. This will make Severus Snape fall in love with me for sure. This is life.




I almost apply this with a screeching laughter.... "Almost"

I wrote my previous review of Death and Decay last year. Then life (and death) happened, and I was caring for a dying person I was very fond of, often wearing this scent while doing so. After she'd passed away, I swapped my bottle, as I did not bear to smell it. Too many associations. I promised myself, though to wait and buy it again in due time. The due time came today, but this time round I went for the solid, as the liquid perfume is of monster strenght.

I do not want to write another review here, just want to share something interesting I heard in a podcast with Carla Valentine, curator of Barts Pathology Museum in London. According to what she said, indole, the chemical we all know so very well from jasmine and other white flowers, can also be found in coffee, chocolate, semen, poop (we also knew that one, right?), of course all kinds of perfumes and last but not least decomposing bodies! Call me morbid, but I find it somehow touching and beautiful. This faithful little aromachemical accompanies us from our conception via all the delights and necessities of life till death and beyond. How nice! From now on, I will officially think of indole as the bridge between this side of the Styx and the Big Unknown Beyond.

Hm. I am happy to own this little beauty again!

A discreet and beautiful scent with fresh smelling dewy lilies and narcotic sweet ylang ylang, with a tiny amount of spices in the background, something like cinnamon. Together it creates a calming light white floral scent with chamomille tea in the evening. Light and non-offensive, yet suitable for winter and fall as well as the spring and summer.

Death and decay is a true winner. I did not realize this was such a polarizing fragrance!
Death and Decay (as explained to me by a store rep in Tokyo, Japan) is not being interpreted correctly. It is meant to represent and highlight its main note of Lily of the Valley in all of its stages of life from vegetative, to floral, to full bloom and then into decay.
The funeral flower (lily) is alive and well i assure you. This is a lush green floral, a beautiful and new idea that carves its way into my heart through its use of natural oils, its balanced and well blended composition and its polarizing affects on people.
Namesake aside, this awesome fragrance is long lasting, stunning stuff.
I'm enamored. I call it a winner in my book!

Death and decay is a lovely thick floral with an overall feeling of lily-of-the-valley, reminiscent of both Idylle and Diorissimo, but less dry and more juicy vegetal, perhaps due to the fact that this one contains some true essential oils (not all natural).
The name is weird and not nice, buut an SA explained the personal experience behind this name. Being lilies typically a funeral flower, one could be mislead, but if you step over this concept you will have a nice thick floral with a fresh edge and quite contemplative. As for many Lush perfumes the final effect and performance are different from mainstream. It smells more of a vegetal smell rather than a trendy smell.
It's an oil so very longlasting, but not very projective.

Smells a bit like a florist shop, lilies and roses, carnations for the spicy touch, and may be jasmine, sliglty wilting flowers....may be wreaths. Indolic flowers.
I can see where the name come from, my mum never liked lilies flowers because "they smell like a cemetery". Well...I really like the smell of florist shops, but I know where this comes from.

Liked it, actually, just tried it on paper, but it's good.
Erm, what a pretty name for a perfume.
This is a sad perfume. It smells like flowers on a casket. It's like an old lady perfume, only the old lady has died
Powdery lilies! Strong yet intimate, like a very perfumey floral body lotion on a sunkissed femal skin. Intense, longlasting. Death and decay? I would rather say HEAVEN.

If you want a perfume smelling of a decaying corpse, gravedirt and slow decomposition, search elsewhere. This is not it. Death and Decay is a lovely, quiet, meditative, melancholy floral. In its mood I could compare it to Lutens's De Profundis, althought they are very different fumes. D&D features powdery florals, probably lilly, ylang-ylang, jasmine and rose. It does remind one of a funeral parlour with large bouquets and wreath of lillies and roses, but the flowers feel somehow muted and distant, as if looked at through tears. I would only wear this fragrance for myself on long autumnal walks, when one contemplates the impermanence of everything, remembers departed loved ones and looks forward to long, long winter evenings. Interesting and beautiful perfume!

Update (15/8) I bought a bottle of this perfume yesterday in the lovely little Gorilla Perfumes Shop in London, and I must slightly amend my review.
Probably I put very little on the smelling strip when I tried it at the launch, because it is not muted at all! It is a rather strong floral perfume, and a rather realistic one, too. It is strong and vivid, one drop is perfectly enough for the whole day. It lasts and lasts forever. I applied my drop at 2 pm, and now at 10 pm it still goes strong. The Death and Decay subject may be expressed by the fact that what I am experiencing is the fragrance of lilies at the precise point in time when they are just about to start wilting. They still look wonderful, but...you know that fragrance of flowers when they've reached their peak and start to slowly turn towards decay. This perfume captures just that moment. Beautiful!

agree that the prices are a bit on the high side even here at my place in asia

this is a must try for me though, im curious how they do lilies.. hope it reaches Lush shops here

What is with the name? Why would you name a perfume "Death & Decay"???? I do find it interesting that this is a scent for both men & women. It also contains both spicy and powdery notes, so curious as to, how well they blend together.
I thought that people were joking when they said this smelt like a nursing home. But oh my god, they were right.

I love this but did have it for half price in the sale and am in the UK. I find it just powdery and sweet on its own and would not reach for it but combined with the Elphba spray it is amazing and I’m sure it’s what brings the balance and the longevity. I literally spray it and can still smell it 24 hours later in the room I’ve sprayed it in. If it comes back I will check it is the same before buying but would spend the full price if it’s the same.

Way back in November 2018, I was given a wonderful gift: the chance to create my own personalized perfume at the Tonatto Parfums boutique in Piazza di Pietra in Rome (which, as far as I know, sadly no longer exists). The resulting composition was so true to me! A powdery, resinous floral with a typical "retro-cosmetic" scent. It had notes of rose, Vanilla, lilac, mimosa, benzoin... One of the few perfumes I've used until the last drop. I unexpectedly found a very similar scent in this Lush body spray, Glinda, in collaboration with the film "Wicked"! It has notes of rose, iris, vanilla, sesame, and benzoin, and has perhaps jumped to the top of my list of favorite Lush body sprays (in terms of strength, it certainly surpasses all the others in my experience!!!). I recommend a sniff to all lovers of these floral, sweet, powdery scents 🥰.

Im so sad that I really do not like this one as much as I'd thought. I'd been looking forward to getting it.

at first it genuinely smells like a nursing home. like wayyy too much rose and nut notes at first. it's SO strong. maybe that's because I typically don't like rose notes too much. it does definitely smell better after a bit. has a great dry down.

I layered this with flowerbomb by Viktor and Rolf and it does surprisingly smell good with it. Pink woods by ari also smells good layered with this.

You just have to give this a bit to smell good.
This smells like bubbles and highnotes im impressed

Upon first smell of this I wasn’t impressed, however it’s one half of a fragrance and can be worn with the Elphaba version! This changes the Fragrance for good ;) both fragrances really bring each other together in such a clever way. I have been wearing Elphaba for months as it’s a really nice, foresty scent. That one can be worn alone, but I think Glinda is kind of sub par on its own! If you haven’t tried yet, try combining them!

I got this perfume as a gift from a co-worker for Christmas! It was the sweetest thing ever, she heard me bring it up as I love Ariana Grande and the thought of owning a Glinda perfume.

Unfortunately, I never got to test it. So when she surprised me with it, I was literally beyond excited to open it and finally get to see what it smelt like.

This perfume is the only perfume I’ve ever had to give away. It is terrible. It’s a huge let down. It smells like it’s a Demeter fragrance titled “Talcum powder”. It’s nauseating. The notes and vibe are completely misleading. I don’t think anyone would think Glinda would smell like this. I will always keep it though as it reminds me of that co worker and how kind her gesture was.

However, I don’t recommend buying this. It’s a waste of money.
smells like a literal nursing home
Glinda Upland, the body spray, by Lush, smells like a body lotion with roses.

Omg this is Turkish Delight in a bottle! Love it! Perfect scent to encapsulate sweet, feminine Glinda. Just like Turkish Delight candy: pink, sweet rose-jam scent with undertones of pistachio/almond and a dusting of powdered sugar. Not too powdery (I detest powdery scents). Glinda is more of a floral (rose) gourmand/sweet with a light dusting of powder which only adds to the softness and feminity. Soft, sweet, girly and fun and not overly synthetic. 10/10

One of my dearest friends gave me this perfume because she found it difficult to wear such a powdery fragrance.

At first I was wary of using it, but I have to admit that, despite not being a revolutionary fragrance, I have ended up developing a certain temporary addiction to this fairy dust.

It smells like a kind of sugary powder (a lot of sugar and a lot of dust) made with roses (as the main ingredient), violets, orris and vanilla.

On my skin it is a practically linear fragrance, although its start is a little more lively and it settles sweeter and powdery, flatter. It has an intense projection and lasts more than 12 hours on me.

I find it a romantic and naive fragrance, clean, relaxing, for use in cold seasons due to its sweet nuance, but only suitable for lovers of powdery perfumes and the rose note.

Scent 6.5/10
Longevity 10/10
Sillage 7/10
Quality/Price 8/10
Versatility 7/10
Packaging 4/10
Would I buy again? Maybe
bubble gum fairy smell, that's it. Princess vibes but no Initiative

I like the comforting powdery rose scent that it leaves, nuttier than rose jam but I wish there were more pistachio and amber. The lush dna is strong in this one like you can TELL it's from Lush because it has that lingering lush smell that all their frags have, this is a shame because I find it a bit offputting since it reminds me of a period in my life where I wore a lot of Lush and it's a period I'd rather not go back to.

I don't think it's as basic as people say though, I've been looking for a decent rose scent because while there may be many out there, none of them are in my collection even though it's a favourite note of mine.

I respect them for not just recycling Snow Fairy and LOM for Wicked like I thought they would. I used to wear the LOM spray a lot and when sampling the Elphaba spray in store (which is not LOM but has similar notes) two seperate people said that it smells like me. I was a little offended because when I smelled it I thought it was rather strong and spicy, but they're not wrong because I do smell like an autumnal bonfire sometimes. I like both sprays, I think £40 is a lot to ask but they project and last forever.

I'm wondering which one to buy, do I do what everyone expects and buy something similar to what I already have or surprise everyone and get this Glinda spray which I prefer, is more agreeable, and is unlike what I own already. Also Wicked is better than you think it's going to be, went in with low expectations and left a convert.

i was planning on blindly buying this because it’s aesthetically perfect.

today i finally got a chance to visit a lush store and they had it in stock - i was so excited because i love everything wicked of course 💕🫧

sadly this smells like one of those canned hair color sprays that you’d get for your halloween costume, you know the really strong-smelling, cheap stuff that you’d have to go outside to use when you were a kid?

it gave me a headache!! i was sooo sad about it!!

the other bath products from the wicked collection are fantastic though - both the glinda and elphaba fragrances were a huge let down :(

This body spray isn't revolutionary by any means, nor is it awful—very middle of the road.

At first spray, it's straight roses. Very floral and heady, slightly powdery, like rose oil. A couple of hours into the wear I start to smell some sweetness with the rose which I feel like is the vanilla starting to emerge. After about four hours, I get a very slight nuttiness from the pistachio but not in any significant way.

This lasted for about 6 hours on me and the sillage was moderate. I was intrigued by the notes but overall underwhelmed. In my opinion, there could have been a stronger concentration of vanilla and pistachio because, otherwise, this is just a very standard rose scent.
I'd agree with @kpop_stan, but it's not that negative to my nose. No rancid notes, but yeah, first something already seen before – rose – then a bit of Play-Doh. Not bad, just okay.
Kind of just smells like the lush store to me. Like a bunch of bath bombs mixed together. It's not unpleasant though

Goodness GRACIOUS this is rancid!!!! In the first couple of minutes it's pleasant and reminds me of something Lush has released in the past, but after 5 minutes or so it just started smelling like play doh. Lame.

Soft, clean, comforting, sweet. I get the rose, the coumarin, the powdery violetty/heliotrope nuances. I don’t get anything nutty or salty. No vanilla. It reminds me of a very light Loukhoum (Keiko Mecheri) more than anything.
It’s sweet but cosmetic at the same time. It never becomes cloying and its gentleness makes it comforting. A rose powder smell with slight hints of musk. A touch of White Musk Libertine as well.
The perfect after bath body spray or before bedtime scent. Not bad at all. Might get a bottle before it runs out.

This starts off as a slightly more powdery Rose Jam, then turns into a slightly more spicy version of Amelie Mae - a lipsticky rose. Really if you've got either of these, you wouldn't need to buy Glinda.

Smells like powdery marshmallows sitting on a bed of vanilla dusted rose petals.
Moderately sweet, soft & delicate.
Not a love, but I like it.

Rose Oil, Palmarosa Oil, Sesame Seed Absolute , Vanilla Absolute, Almond oil, Orris, Benzoin, Coumarin

Citrusy rose with a hint of creamy sweetness. Imagine Rose Jam mixed with Creamy Candy and you have something like Glinda. I don’t think I’d have guessed that this has pistachio and sesame in the notes because the rose is pretty dominant but the almond here is creamy and sweet - it’s kinda similar to the way the Almond comes across in Space Girl. All this is to say that this is very identifiable as a Lush perfume. It’s a decent strength and has a decent longevity for a body spray (better on clothes!).

I struggle with the Rose note in Rose Jam, Amelie Mae and No Way To Say Goodbye but this is probably the most wearable Rose I’ve tried from Lush. I think that if you like Rose Jam you’re likely to be into this one, but you might also be safe with it if you like American Cream, Creamy Candy, Space Girl or even the Barbie perfume.
I can't wait to try this!!! 🫧🫧🫧

First, I'm a big Lush fan. Have been for decades.
But, when I first sprayed this on, I was ...confused. I smelled ..dandelions! I've NEVER smelled dandelion in a perfume before! ...within a couple minutes it was sharply green, dandelion weed..with a strange bittersweet something in the background. Not saying that they ACTUALLY used dandelion, but that was how it smelled on me. That faded after about 10 minutes.

Not violet at all, imo..I have many violet perfumes including a couple bottles of the very hard to find Belanciaga Paris...also, Kerbside Violet and V by Lush. I just don't smell violet in this.

It actually smelled like something was a bit off in the blend. The sharp greenness mixed with a bitter coffee in the opening,..the coffee doesn't blend well, it's better when it goes away ..it's like something didn't match up right.

Emma Dick is the perfumer and I want to ask Why, Emma ..why? Why bitter coffee? Why not white chocolate or a tea note or something less clashing? Ah, well. 🤷

SO-
The longer it was on, the more wearable it became. I smell a LOT of rose in the drydown. It IS quite original, I will say that.
Lush website advertises this as a wedding perfume and speaks of Jordan Almonds...no..I smelled no almond at all, which is too bad. Almond would've been better than bitter coffee.

It has very good projection and nice longevity. You won't smell it but everyone else will. And, in the drydown, I got compliments.

Again, the DRYDOWN is a BEAUTIFUL slightly green floral.. eventually. And that's the most important part, the part you live with.
But getting there ...well, it's a challenge. When I'm on the fence I let my guy decide and he gave a thumbs up.

I can't say this is a safe blind buy, though.

Fresh and green with violet being the star of this fragrance. Lots of pear right from the bottle and when sprayed, but the dry down on my skin has only a hint of pear. The longer this sits on the skin the more palatable it becomes, turning into a lighter powdery violent scent that is more ozonic on me, but doesn't have much projection. I don't smell any coffee or sandalwood so I'm not sure where that is coming from lol. If you like the Daddy-O shampoo from lush this is that with a sweeter more feminine twist. For some reason I also think that if you enjoy the 'Alina' fragrance from lush you would like this one as well.
To me its also very different than Lush's other violet fragrances, V and Kerbside Violet.

Wearing this today. Pungent green, vegetal to begin with, then goes sweet, so I get the “sugared” but not the almonds at all. Almond is a very distinctive note. Do not get coffee or pear whatsoever. That said, what I do get is strange and quite beautiful. There’s a hay like note in the drydown. Do not get sandalwood either. Bit of a trickster this one.

My nose isn’t so well tuned yet but I think I can smell coffee and almonds only on my skin. I smell fresh pear and roses covered in a dusty powder in the air and on my clothes. It lasts a long time on me. There is a very fresh and green quality as others state.
It wasn’t love at first or even tenth wear. I thought it was too feminine for me. I gave my sister a sample and loved it on her and so I tried a few more times and I love it now.
I did have a sample of lipstick rose for comparison. Lipstick Rose is smooth and refined and so incredibly well blended. LR is luxurious and elegant, the gold standard for vintage make up/lipstick perfumes imho.
In comparison, confetti is screechy and sharp, a little off. I personally know someone it is headache inducing for….but not me!… and I do prefer Confetti over other similars, I’m a Lushy and it just suits me much better and I feel more comfortable wearing it. It better suits me and my being. It does not smell like Rose Jam to me.
I'm fine without compliments and I’m even more ok if it keeps people away from me haha. But really, it does smell good and I love it so much more now that I’ve been wearing it a couple seasons.

I was so excited to get my bargain bottle on eBay, & so wanted to love it!

Sadly, & disappointingly, to & on me, this is a very expensive (if at full price!) Devil's Nightcap with a woody Rose Jam dry down. Nothing else.

Also gave me such a headache, that I know it's not worth giving it another try to see whether or not I get anything different.

Will be re-selling this one! 😷🤕

Can’t explain why but I absolutely adore this perfum, the opening is quit strong and kinda tickles but it settles in a relaxing and comforting smell, definitely rosy and powdery but with a touch of papier d’Arménie, which makes me love it more then lipstick rose for this very reason. I look forward to wearing my clothes that still have the smell left on it <3
only critic is that my skin doesn’t keep the smell that much ;( but that might be just my skin lol

on my skin this is a smoky rose with a bit of incense in it
if you know rose jam, this is a tone down rose jam from lush with a bit of incense / wood thrown in
unisex and would say safe for office wear
a stincky mess, a chaos that gives headache...create by E. Dick ...of course.

I just tried a decant of this, and it gave me a headache immediately. Almost makes me nauseated to smelled this for too long. I also got dizzy shortly after. I don't know what is in this that did that to me. This takes beast mode to a whole different level. I really wanted to like this, but Its just sooo sharp and overwhelming.
Selling this if anyone wants this. Didn’t like how it smelled on me.

I don't know what notes are on here because the one I smelled at the store smells like jasmine.
For whatever reason they copied pasted the same exact smell in their "Ginger" perfume only made it more masculine with undertones of tobacco and banana peel. They didn't have a tester for Ginger for 3 months and the sales rep kept saying that the scent is clear from the bottle. It turned out as masculine as Boss No 1 even though it was marketed as Unisex. Well, anyways, you live & you learn.

This is very much lush’s take on lipstick rose. The rawness of lush doesnt go well with it. What makes lipstick rose good is the perfect nuanced roundness of it. Theres something a little screechy, a little green, a little sour about this. If you like this and havent already, try lipstick rose.

This hits you with sweet prickly pear and vanilla and then dries down into a sweet woody scent. The pear stays but it turns more into a candy-sweet smell. It's beautiful.

I've had this perfume for a while now. I only wear it for days I want to smell very sweet because the sillage is intense.

I will say that while I was in Rome, Italy, I smelt this smell everywhere in natural areas. So now it pleasantly reminds me of Italy :)

I blind bought a FB on ebay a while ago. I was just curious about the notes and the price was just fine. Quite interesting. To me it smells like suguered almonds + violet with a sniff of coffee. This is the only perfume with coffee as a note that I own. I like the smell of coffee but I don't want to smell like it. So far the coffee note in that one is light enough that it is easily wearable.

Opens with a big hit of sandalwood then gives off huge dark mossy vibes which remind me greatly of Devil's Night Cap (is that the coffee?) Eventually the scent takes a big 180 and becomes quite sweet and fresh leaving you with a rosy musky drydown.

It smells like jasmine green tea, talc and soap.
In fact it smells like Luxe's Camelia Aloe soap.
Gorgeous complex candied violet. Now discontinued. Get a bottle while you still can!

Okay, so I liked this, but it smells IDENTICAL to a Mid East oil I got on my honeymoon in Dubai all those years ago...
I ended up getting 6 then, and in many ways, that trip kickstarted this obsession-hobby, so for me, this was a bit of a throwback, of sorts...
The coffee note burns off quickly, or, it's overtaken and held in check early. The rose-pear accord is inSANE, it's cloyingly sweet, and if I'm being honest with myself, possibly a little too sweet.
The violet leaf note is minor, but sorta holds the sweetness and bitterness together...
I like this, but I already have something reaaally similar to this already...!

Initial spray smells like coffee liqueur (kahlua) and not exactly coffee (there’s a difference I swear) because this is sweeter and greener, it kinda smells like coffee and green tea mixed together. On the dry down it’s all just the soft and powdery violets. I don’t know where the rose and pear are I can’t smell them very much but this is a genius fragrance because I’ve never encountered this before where the initial spray smells nothing like the dry down

On my skin (which is clearly different to many other peoples experience of this scent!) Confetti is fresh violets plus leaves, Parma Violet sweets, bright and fresh with a hint of bitter black coffee. It stays like that for an hour or so before it starts to change and a sugared almond scent peeks through and mixes with the violet. the deep deep dry down is dragée, but not cloyingly sweet.

Love it, it's beautiful! Goes perfectly with my hair after I use Lush Daddy-O shampoo and Candy Rain Conditioner.

If it helps give you an idea of what to expect, I feel like this smells like an old-school British sweet shop that sells Parma violets, violet & rose creams, coffee creams, fudge and sugared almonds. It's a very different vibe to some modern sweet shops filled with herscheys, twinkies, sweet tarts and caramels, which is much more of a Aquolina Pink Sugar scent!

This perfume made me realize I'm not the biggest fan of "green floral" scents. They don't mix well with my natural chemistry and are too sharp for my nose. However, the scent itself is nice (I'm a floral whore) and lasts a good amount of time (8 hr+). With that said, I definitely don't get the "almond" vibe Lush was trying to make this out to be.

Confetti is a quietly impressive fragrance if you're able to distinguish the scent from the name and marketing. I think the coffee and sandalwood create the impression of nuttiness, and the pear, though not a particularly detectable note on its own, gives it a hint of sweetness. I can see how sweet nuttiness evokes the feel of candied almonds, but this is in no way a literal representation of what's going on in Confetti. Instead, it's a green floral with a hint of something roasted and nutty, dusted with sugar. I find it earthy and calming. It's not evocative of weddings, and it's too serene to be particularly celebratory, but it's very nice.

I really wanted to like Confetti and the early stage was really promising. But the drydown comes rather quickly, is really boring and lasts forever. Something generic in the base, which doesn't match the notes list. In my experience this is common to the few Lush perfumes (liquids, not solids) that I have tried, there is a forever lingering incense-like close to skin smell in the drydown.

I do not detect roses, nor violets when applied on skin. What a shame!

I bought Confetti when it was on sale and I think it is not worth the money on normal price. Luckily there is many other alternatives to choose from and I am not stuck with Lush products :-)

Soooo delicious when I sniffed it at the store. I was put off by the name “confetti” because I thought the smell would be like sugar sprinkles and cotton candy..i don’t know why i thought that. This has an ancient, earthly vibe with dark Turkish roses sitting like a jewel inside incense, woods, spices, and florals rounding it out. It smelled insanely delicious and of all the available perfumes, this was one of the hardest to stop sniffing, and I smelled like 7 of them. I didn’t buy this at the store cause they didn’t have solid perfumes and I already bought lust and pansy and dirt and didn’t want to overspend, but I really should have cause they don’t sell it in lush USA..only in lush U.K and its a large expensive bottle there only : (.

Lush has unique, impressive violet scents like 'Kerbside Violet' and 'Fantabulosa' in their roster. How does 'Confetti' fare? Not very well.
This is named incorrectly. I agree with SailorV, there are no candied almonds or anything remotely nutty in here. I also +1 'Iris Dragees' & as a cheapie Zara 'MSK/NTL' as true candied almonds / confetti.

You know what this is closest to? Insolence EDP by Guerlain, but heavier and with rose oil. Beginning is a blast of thick fermented roses with powdery sweet violets. There is an extremely bitter coffee facet that fades away after an hour. It's not coffee, but the bitterness of it, similar to what you get in Lush's 'Cardamom Coffee'. I get nothing fruity, Pears who?
SailorV is also spot on with the 90s lipstick vibe because guess what... This smells identical to Lancôme and L'Oréal's signature lipstick scent. Just much heavier. The violets get sweeter, thicker and powdery as it dries down, otherwise quite linear.
This is not ''cool and damp'' but rather thick, fermented and heady.

Projection is average, but longevity is great. This is on the heavier side of Lush's perfume portfolio and becomes extremely pungent in warm environments.
For comparison: Fantabulosa is also a violet perfume but is much airier and youthful.

I am sorry to say but, this is such an unimpressive scent with no edge to it. Is it 'Lush'y? No. Is it niche worthy quality? No. Is it worth wearing as a natural fragrance? That's your call.
After experiencing Fantabulosa, Superworld Unknown, Breath of God...Confetti is your run of the mill heavy makeup powder / lipstick fragrance. Not worth the price tag.

This was named Confetti because it reminded some people at Lush of the candied almonds served at weddings. And I don't understand that at all. It's a violet scent to me, no almonds in sight. If you want candied almonds, try Reminiscence Dragee instead.
That doesn't mean Confetti is bad, just misnamed. It opens with a spicy green blast of violet leaves and flowers. For a moment I can sense the pear and coffee note, but they move far into the background really quick. If you test this at the Lush store with a mask on they're easy to miss, at least this is how it was for me the first two times I tried it. The violet is intense though. It's sweet, dewy and slightly spiced. Now that I think about it, the scent is quite close to a violet dragee instead of an almond one. But blended with the rose it also reminds me of glossy 90s and 2000s lipsticks. The ozonic green leaves are noticeable, too, so several facets of violets are present in this perfume. In the drydown the scent finally turns more powdery with the sandalwood warming it up.
I wish the other notes were a little more present next to the violet, but that's just my personal taste. This is a nice sweet floral and quite strong, easily projecting through a leather jacket with one spray. Contrary to some other perfumes by this brand it doesn't smell like the Lush store or like bath bombs and doesn't have a homemade vibe, so it could work even for people who aren't big fans of Lush.

This perfume is pure sugar and I love it! Depending on the situation, the opening is either very green or very reminiscent of Hale's Blue Boy syrup which is a great nostalgic blast of one of my favorite sugary drinks growing up. It's cream soda, a little almond, a little caramel and very, very yummy. I don't find it over bearing but I have yet to try it on a very warm day.
