It dries down to a very flattering sweet sandalwood scent. It's probably not for every day but I think it smells great and gives me joy whenever I smell it.

I know that this perfume is named after candied almonds that people find at weddings, to my nose this comes across as ozonic-salty smelling. This is shocking to me because I would expect something that is gourmand, sweet and crunchy. I kept smelling my wrist to deconstruct the smell in my head and I realize that this effect is what violet brings to the composition.

I do smell coffee, but it is not as strong as the coffee in Cardamom & Coffee. I can detect rose and sandalwood as well. But somehow, the sandalwood in it does not bring the creamy effect that I normally find in sandalwood based fragrance. It stays dry and sharp to my nose. Thankfully, I cannot trace any pear scent, which I detest.

All and all, this is an intriguing smell and it rough around the edges.

I love violet perfumes and I really dislikes most rose perfumes. This perfume has both violet and rose and I wanted to try it anyway because of the violet. I wish I hadn't bought it, I couldn't go to a Lush store so I just bought it.
At first all I can smell is rose and something weird, something old. After a while the rose smell is gone, only the weird smell is left and a headache.

Tested today. Initial spray it’s mostly rose & violet. I can smell the fresh green violet tho’ only for a few minutes. After 10 mins it’s a sweet sort of gourmandy rose mostly, the violet is gone. It reminded me strongly of TF Cafe Rose. That puzzled me - but I was unaware of a coffee note in this until I came here to write this review....So that explained that anyway! I can’t detect distinct almond here at any stage. I expected pink & lilac tinted sugared almonds, but maybe Italian Confetti is different to the sugared almonds we have in the UK?
Unfortunately, after about an hour this turns absolutely rank on my skin, very sour, dusty & quite unpleasant. I think it’s the rose combined with synthetic woody base? On the paper strip it still smells Ok - & still reminds me of Cafe Rose. I just don’t think this suits my chemistry at all - it smells just plain bad in the dry down...oh well. As ever, just my experience,ymmv.

Confetti is a potpourri made of roses and violets with something bitter green. And a portion of confectioners' sugar. It has a very distinct vintage makeup note. That particular pressed powder smell. Personally I like that, but I can see how it can appear "stale" or like mothballs to someone else.

I have two lovely body powders from LUSH that I use sparingly: Ginger and Silky Underwear. Confetti smells like a combination of those.

Almonds are listed among the notes, and I have a weakness for marzipan (both in perfumery and food) but to be honest I can't smell almonds distinctly. There is a nice, almost nutty sweetness to Confetti, but not necessarily almonds.

There is nothing remotely ozonic or aquatic in this, to my nose, which I'm grateful for. (ozonic smells make me queasy)

No distinct coffee note either.

Overall this is a nice, bitter-sweet, powdery fragrance with an unusual green twist, and different layers that add to its complexity. Fun name too!

Powdery fresh aquatic roses, sugar dusted with a dash of almond. The almond notes make the sugar not too sugary ror cloying, just nice and pleasant. I do love my rose-violet perfumes, and this one is one of the greenest I owned. Thankfully the aquatic rose doesnt turn sour on my skin (some roses does). and the powdery rose, is not the heavy dried potpourri roses... they are fresh and just nice. love.

Rose, violet and sugared almonds. What it claims to be basically. Green to start with with vioet leaf I like the opening a lot but it dries as a sugary sweet rose. Not my favourite, a bit sweet for my tastes but pleasant enough on the odd occasion. Not a daily perfume for me.

To me this smells familiar. Im thinking Turkish delight. Rosey and sweet, but also green, but also dry, like dried rose petals... A "pot pourri" or "drawer liner" accord. Blends well with lush ginger for some base. I think those two scents together have a life of their own. Very strong. Female scent typically, but my mouth would probably water if I smelt it on a guy. 😉

I bought this impulsively in the store because I was so taken aback by this scent! My senses are confused, in the best way.

This fragrance has an entire storyline, a beginning/middle/and end! Just like Lush’s older fragrances (The smell of weather turning, etc.)

It opens with a WARM, woody, cinnamon-y chocolate coffee note. The dry down happens so softly, before you know it this delicate and powdery doll-head violet is present, mixed with rose and damp earth. If you know Lush’s violets, you know they are DEWY. humid.

It’s a thrill of a scent. ADDICTIVE! It’s ~simultaneously~ always two sides of each coin and I just can’t figure out how. Unisex, yet both “delicate” and “robust”. Woody, and dry- yet sweet and full of humidity. Vague and comforting yet definitely not a people pleaser. Every single element is tangible at all times - ITS A PUZZLE TO ME ENTIRELY.

Definitely spray it ON skin when you’re in the mall next! Walk around!

This really does smell like pure roses, violets and sugar. Really delightful girly scent. Totally sugared almonds plus violets. I smell no coffee or pear. I do smell a base of sandalwood which gives a perfect balance but does not overpower the scent.❤️

It is interesting as it says "Amber Floral" - where is Amber in the notes?

In the article fragrantica says it is Floral Chypre: where is oakmoss, labdanum and bergamot? Or at least patchouli + vetiver?

I had high hopes for this scent, because Ouch110 spoke highly about this one (and I love coffee and almonds, so I thought it must be lovely...)

Well thank goodness I tested it - everyone's nose is different - and what a let-down this was for me, personally...

From the first moment on, to me it smells like grass and hay - not dry but moist and balmy, and yet powdery at the same time, like smelling green bananas mixed with fresh cut grass (is this the scent of violet leaf??). It's very unpleasant for me.

It definitely made me think that I am smelling iris/orris. I'm surprised that wasn't featured in the notes.

No coffee, no almonds. But then again, it was so unpleasant I didn't want to keep smelling it so I scrubbed it off after half an hour or so.

Not recommended for people who aren't into green powdery scents.

Dewy and super green in the opening, but the opening only lasts a few seconds. It quickly dries down to green violets and rose with a slight undertone of coffee. It certainly has a quality reminiscent of sugared almonds, but I think it smells closer to Rockets candies. The rose comes off as a bit jammy, which reminds me of a more sophisticated version of Rose Jam. This is like an airier, greener Montale Intense Cafe with violets. Very pretty! New favourite spring scent for morning or casual occasions.

Notes according to my nose (in order of prominence): ionone and green violets, jammy rose, coffee bean

I was looking for a perfume with rose and violet leaf combination. I tried La Douceur De Siam Dusita sample but it left me disappointed when it lasted a whole two hours on me for such an expensive perfume. So, I was hanging out in a Lush store trying out perfumes since I have a gift card and the SA pointed out Confetti saying that this is limited edition. I don't like coffee note so was a bit hesitant. Thank god, I can't smell the coffee note but the first blast was a refreshing rose scent, sweetened by the pear. The dry down is the best part, a matcha tea and almond combination. Weird, right, at least on my skin, that's what I get. The scent last 6 hours and I get whiffs of rose throughout. This is a winner in my books.
It's a bit like a LUSH mash-up of different scents. It did not knock my socks off . I will go back and re-test. Expected more VIOLET.

Some of my favorite Lush scents are violet (Tuca Tuca and Bathos), so I was excited for a new violet offering. The main note I get is sour, talc-y rose. Very vintage smelling. The violet is green and fresh, and faintly reminds me of Bathos. Confetti smells better further away, wafting off of me instead of having my nose directly pressed to it.
I think you need to like vintage florals to fully enjoy this one.

Lord, what a shame!!! I absolutely love the opening, it smells exactly like violet sweets over a sort of foresty base. But after a few minutes it is 100% cloves on my skin, which happens to be one of my least favorite fragrance notes. I even compared it to dried cloves in my kitchen and it's exactly the same smell. I don't know if it's like this to everyone or if Confetti and I just don't have chemistry. Scrubbed either way.

The first blast is slightly odd, but within a few minutes it settles into a lush (!) creamy, rose/violet sweetness. Yes it's definitely reminscent of sugared almonds, but there's a waxy/creaminess that keeps it from being 100% gourmand. A good thing, to my nose, since I like gourmands to smell like perfume - not an exact copy of foody scent. I wouldn't have thought of coffee unless I knew it was there, but it adds a roundness and edge which is nice.

This also reminds me of Lipsalve, one they don't make any more, I find it soothing and very pleasant, and though I don't usually go for sweet perfumes, this is lovely. The drydown has something like a woody labdanum that's quite earthy. Remind sme of Miller Harris perfumes.

I think it would suit anyone who enjoys a flirty feminine perfume that's high quality.

Sillage is noticable, longevity very good.
these are bitter almonds, overall its not some bright sunny perfume, its caramelized almonds, gourmand perfume, violets draw attention, but its a pass for me this time.

This is so good! Green and sweet at the same time! I smell violet leaf, a little touch of rose, and a honeyed, powdery base. It seems to me like a greener version of Loukhoum Eau poudree (Keiko Mecheri), that I absolutely love, more than the original version, and I'm wearing often in these days. I can't smell sandalwood, pear or coffee at all.

I purchased a bottle of this in the Edinburgh Spa store, just after i had a 'Renaissance' treatment downstairs in the spa. (Which was completely magical!)

Confetti reminded me of Charity Pot body lotion, but with lashings of violet and coffee notes. One of those scents that you sniff and keep coming back for more!

Wow this is an unusual one for sure. It's one of my two favourites from the Florence exclusive perfumes from Lush.

It's an unusual powdery green, lots of violet leaf with coffee. A weird mix that works! I sometimes feel a fleeting whoosh of pear/banana when it's first sprayed to so, this one is all over the place in it's olfactory group. It feels planty and stemmy and dusted with violet powder. The coffee is a great surprise considering I would never think that a roasted brown feeling note would work with a green composition. It's a winner!!

:)

What a gorgeous scent that is brilliantly blended with two seemingly contrasting notes, i.e. violet and coffee. The final composition is rich and sensual. The lipsticky/leathery violet and the gourmandy coffee are married to create a surreal floral that is beyond this world.

A must try.
This smells like a broom i only bought it because i have the glinda one and i wanted the set i did test wear this its not that bad just dislike it alot

I am sure there are inconsistencies in the making of this spray. For me it smells primarily of black pepper then a woodsy smell. I bought it in the sale but would buy again if it smelt the same. I spray in on my body and clothes and when I go back into the same room 24 hours later I can still smell it. Very similar to Lord of Misrule perfume in its vibe but with much longer longevity. I do mix it with the Glinda spray and I wonder if that makes it last longer. I definitely wouldn’t wear it to work as I think others would find it overpowering.

JuliaToothFairy is spot on - it's impossible to rate this using the notes above because they're entirely incorrect !

On spraying I immediately got a blast of citronella which ironically I didn't get when I tried it in store, so I'm guessing those top notes are rather volatile and already softened as it had been open awhile.
Fortunately they evaporate and soften quite quickly and instead you do get a lemony tea note with something a little spicy which is reminiscence of one of that originals: Ginger ( I actually used to distribute the products for Cosmetics to Go which was a forerunner to Lush and this was available back then ). It's only after quite some time to the woody notes come through which does improve it quite a lot. I would find it completely unwearable otherwise, as I'm really not fond of bug spray ( I also get bug spray from Jicky, so maybe I'm just weird !!). In fact , it was the dry down that made me purchase this, because a couple hours later it was actually smelling really nice, as I walked around.

I do think they missed a trick though. I really hoped the green theme would have inspired something , well, green and we'd have something akin to maybe Guardian of the Forest or Grass or even better Tramp ( but that perhaps would be hoping for too much !) Also whatever you do don't go on the scent of the shower gel because it's entirely different. I bought a small bottle and it's some sweet, sickly, boiled sweet* scent. Unless that's your thing, obviously ! ( *hard candy )

I'm afraid these days I'm frequently disappointed with Lush and so rarely bother. I would say 80% of what they produce as either largely unwearable ( a few random essential oils thrown together, unblended, totally discordant and not suitable as a fragrance ) or just playing to popular tastes and could be found cheaper elsewhere ( something sweet with notes of marshmallow, chocolate and vanilla ) . Which is a shame because when they did occasionally get it right, they got it really right. It's just hard to believe this is the same company that produced things like Kerbside Violet; The Devil's Nightcap, Tramp, and Lord of Misrule. *Sigh*

Elphaba Thropp, the body spray, by Lush, smells like grated ginger and lemon.

Ignore the listed notes. I don't understand why the notes listed by Lush are never what you smell in their fragrances.

There are not a lot of perfumes that would straight up disgust me, but this is one of them.

Stupidly blind bought and sold it the next day. First of all, the price is ridiculous. Lush started doing all that FOMO thing and making all limited edition stuff even more expensive - I hate it. Anyway, back to the topic - to sum up, this spray smells like holidays in a dumpster.

Celery, distinctive aroma of raw meat and dirt mixed with mold. It's gross. I can't believe someone thought it'll be a good idea to make a dumpster scent, especially Lush. Weird interperation of what Elphaba smells like!

Shoutout to everyone who doesn’t like this fragrance because it leaves more for those of us who can appreciate this gem. This is my first Lush Body Spray (it took my nose a while to adjust to Lush’s dna) and I am thrilled. So much in fact, I may have to buy a backup before this collab has run its course.

This is the most perfect simple, woody vanilla. If you’re a fan of Eau Duelle, Commodity Gold, or any non-gourmand vanillas, this is for you. This is simple without being boring, yet, is unique and many people won’t be smelling like it. There’s also a natural quality about this that I love, especially as most body sprays tend to smell synthetic (which makes sense given the ingredients).

Three words: grounded, assured and woody.


EDIT 1: after wearing for a few days consistently after I purchased it, this is a bit more herbal and aromatic than I initially thought. It smells like lemongrass and vanilla. Still just as good, but definitely vibrant. Could easily be worn in warmer weather as well.
One of my favourites from lush. Leaning masculine. A cosy peppery woodsy scent. Pairs so well with vanillary. Would buy if it was priced like their regular range and not almost double.
Absolute love!! But I don’t wear it. I spray my curtain and furniture with it. And the floors of my car. Love this as a room scent! I bought back ups! This should be permanent!
celery bomb

i love this scent!! i typically go for more gourmand fragrances so the glinda body spray was more my speed. luckily, i picked up samples of both because my lush didn’t have them in store yet and i live too far to try them once they did. i like to layer this with the glinda body spray as lush suggests and it’s heavenly. the perfect amount of vanilla and sweetness, but also not too sweet that it’s sickening. this is nice for when i want a sweet perfume without possibly making myself nauseous in my own scent bubble 😅 it also lasts forever ! i put this on christmas morning when i got it, and woke up after sleeping and still smell it without having to hold my wrist up to my nose. 10/10 lush! just wish the price wasn’t so high. $100 for two 200ml body sprays is pretty steep especially when they recommend you get both. but also lush’s body sprays are beastmode, they’re way stronger than any typical body spray, closer to an EDT than anything.
a lot of pink pepper, and then just vanishes. Not that much spicy, definitely soft spicey. And flat
elphaba would NOT smell like this EW

This is an interesting and welcome departure from the usual gourmand and floral body mists.

At first spray, it's peppery and piney—very green and like Pine Sol with an edge. The spice and cedar go well together. After about an hour, the coniferous tinge fades and leaves you with a bit of the pink pepper but a mostly, generally woodsy scent.

After about three hours, the vanilla starts to come out and mixes with what's left of the pepper to make a lovely sweet and soft, warm spicy accord. For the remainder of the wear, it's sweet woods from the vanilla and cedar.

Overall, this is a decent body mist and I enjoyed it more than the Glinda Upland spray. The longevity is good too, lasting on me for about 8 hours.

celery juice and grass??
HELP LMAO

Lol. Had to create an account to share my thoughts on this "perfume". Have you ever seasoned a piece of meat with lemon pepper seasoning and thought, "Hmm, I want this on my body." Then look no further! Lush was able to craft a perfume that truly encapsulates lemon pepper seasoning with the dry down of pinesol! I asked my grandma to smell me and now she is in the hospital, doctors told me to wait outside because I smell like a biohazard. Not for me, not for my grandma, not for anyone with a nose.

The opening is just pepper and takes a while to dry down into something more tolerable. If you can manage to get through the opening, you will smell a fresh spicy lemon lime scent. Still not good, still not getting vanilla at all. This was not worth the price and most definitely not worth the headache. Plus side is that has longevity, but is that really a plus when you smell like a meat seasoning?

I don't recommend this to anyone, not even as a room spray either. If you love it, I love that for you! But it aint for me.
Best body spray in this year! Sweet, seductive and vibrant. Totally wearable! Buy it before gone!!!

Zesty lemon pepper on top of a Guardian Of The Forest style green & dry woods.
Gets a bit sweeter on the dry down when the Vanilla shines through.
This is nice.

A fuller set of notes - Hiba Wood Oil, Cedarwood Absolute, Vanilla Absolute, Sicilian Lemon Oil, Pink Pepper Oil, Cardamom Absolute, Coumarin, Oakmoss Extract.

This starts off like a citrussy forest and ends up in a candy store lined with Cedarwood. It goes through a pink pepper stage too but the deep dry down is very candy sweet - that classic Lush combination of Vanilla and Coumarin that you get in American cream... that kind of vibe, so it's sweet but it's not a just vanilla. If you're into Lord of Misrule then this one is quite a different feel imho.

It's really quite magical when it dries down but it's honestly a bit challenging in the beginning so it needs time! I tested it in store and didn't buy it but but then I got on the tube and kept getting whiffs of this beauty so I'll probably have to go back and pick a bottle up! I suspect the scent trail from this one is amazing because the scent bubble around me was so comforting. I found the scent I caught in the air to be nicer than when I put my nose to my skin, but towards the end of the night my skin smelt like what I could smell around me.

A bit pricy for a body spray but it's 200ml and it's a similar strength to a lot of modern edt's so I think it's worth it. This lasts for ages and gets increasingly sweet, so it could become sickly to some people. Guardian of the Forest would be a better choice for anyone who doesn’t enjoy very sweet perfumes and Lord of Misrule would be better, if you're after a less candy-like green vanilla!.

I can see the similarity to Eilish 3 but I find this one more creamy and a little bit less like a Christmas tree. It's got the wood and leaves from a forest but not too many pine needles! Just to also mention - Bare from And Fragrances (by ex-lush perfumer Simon Constantine) also has crossovers with Eilish 3 and Elphaba, but I think the fact that Elphaba is less piney than both makes it easier to wear!
Even though it doesn’t smell like the hair primer it’s still delicious

Thanks, I hate it. I got this as a body butter and because the spray hit me with the same feeling, I’m writing this now:
This is horrible. I’m trying my hardest to empty this as I hate waste, but it’s so hard. The smell fills the whole room, even after hours and hours of reapplying it, my skin strongly still smells of it. It doesn’t go with any of my perfumes and thus I use it only in the evening and only for my legs and feet.

Weirdly enough, this smelt horrible on me but great on my friend. On me, it just smelt like I had bathed myself in expired milk, but tried to cover up with lemons. But when my friend put it on her it gave off the vibe of a buttery, lemony, and vanilla cookie. Buyer beware, do not blind buy.
I really like this perfume. On me it’s like vanilla cookies with a hint of lemon. At first it was very intense, but as with a lot of other lush fragrances it settles, it’s perfect

I don’t understand all the negative reviews on this, I bought this today after trying it in store on two separate occasions, and once it settles down it’s SO good. It literally smells like the hair of a Bratz doll. It has something very nostalgic to it and for a body spray the scent is actually quite complex. I personally really love it!!
thank god i didnt blind buy this!!! smells like sour milk, vomit and lemon cleaning wipes ... what the frick

I actually really like it!! Ive been hearing so many mixed reviews but it seems like some batches can vary. When I first tested the leave in conditioner it was waaaayyy too citrusy. It gave me a headache for the rest of the day. It was so disappointing because everyone just said it smelled like vanilla and lactonic. The body spray is much more tolerable when it comes to the citrus notes.

Horrendous! I was so looking forward to it after the amazing Sticky Dates and I hoped to smell another super cool gourmand. But this smells like the whole Lush shop combined in one fragrance.
So imagine the scent you get when you walk into the Lush shop...that's how Super Milk smells like. It smells like every bath bomb combined in the whole Lush shop.
Sadly not for me.

The opening on this is SHARP! Almost spicy. At first spray I thought it didn’t really smell like the hair primer at all, But after a few minutes it settles and is much closer. I don’t think it’s quite as creamy as the hair primer but overall pretty darn close. I wish they’d bring the perfume back too a that they would keep this one around. It’s pricey for a body spray but lasts longer than any other body spray I own and projects a lot more.

There is actually quite similar to Kerosene's Unknown Pleasures, to the point where i have to squint to notice the differences.

Sipping bergamot tea under a lemon tree in a glasshouse, while having a cake with marshmallow-y frosting on the side.

It's nice, but redundant since I own Kerosene's Unknown Pleasures, which also lasts longer and has a more nuanced profile. I appreciate the sentiment in the scent, though.

This is a review for the glitter spray version. Long winded so bear with me.

Okay. When the Super Milk hair primer first came out I got a free sample from Lush. I wasn't impressed with the formula or the fragrance. It smelled like very burnt French toast with some maple syrup. Would've been good without the burnt aspect. I then wrote off this fragrance as "meh."

Flash forward to April 2025. I saw they had the glitter sprays on display at the register when checking out. Out of curiosity, I sprayed it on my arm right before leaving. The initial smell was a sharp lemon / licorice. Again, I wrote it off as "meh." Very surprised by the hype surrounding this fragrance. Then, probably 10 minutes into my drive home, I started to smell something very nice. I smelled my arm, and it was the glitter spray! As the day went on and it dried down further, I liked it even more. I decided that I would purchase it and give it a try.

I ordered a bottle for myself late August. Once it arrived, I sprayed it, and OMG! It was so synthetic! It had a sort of metallic licorice smell the entire duration of it sitting on my arm! Ended up scrubbing it off after an hour. I was BEYOND disappointed. Lush is known to have pretty hit or miss fragrances with different batches, so I figured I got a bad bottle. I tossed it in my gym bag and forgot about it.

Last week I was cleaning out my gym bag and stumbled upon this confusing spray. Again, I decided to give it a try now that it has been opened for over a month. And it was even BETTER than the sample spray at the store in April! This perfume has given me so much whiplash, but now that it has finally settled, this is simply incredible.

With all of that being said, here are my final thoughts : Great longevity for a body spray, lasts 5 hours. The dry down is very reminiscent of the Josie Maran Vanilla Vibez body butter, they smell almost identical to me. There is a slightly sharp lemon-y opening that smells VERY MUCH like Avocado Co-Wash from Lush, but without the throat tickling incense note. The dry down is more of a creamy, lactonic, COLD vanilla... like vanilla ice cream rather than a vanilla cake. But still much more appropriate for fall / winter than spring / summer. It may take some trial and error to find the version that you prefer, but I definitely recommend the glitter spray above all else. I also think this is great for people who tend to get tired of gourmands quickly. It's delicious, edible, and sweet, but not in a way that is too cloying or overly food-ish. Great value, great longevity, and an overall delicious fragrance!

Just smells like marshmallows with a touch of lemon. I didn't expect to like this, as I found Avocado Co-Wash too intense for me (I assumed they would be similar), and I wasn't loving it that much for the first ten minutes, but it becomes more pleasant to my nose as it dries down. I've never tried any other Super Milk products, so I'm not comparing to the rest of the line. Might have to go back for this one.

Update: I ended up buying a bottle, and alas, it was too artificial on me and I had to return it. May be a batch difference, as I did a skin test the first time I tried in store and didn't have this problem.

Why does it turn from good to bad? Like something is very unnatural and fake, unable to tolerate it after 1 hour of spraying. I expected alot from this scent but unfortunately did not meet my expectations at all!

It seems like the batches vary a lot on this one, but the one I got was first a much more synthetic-smelling lemon candy (compared to the more fresh lemon of the hair primer), and then went straight through to a very strong burnt sugar biscuit scent, which remained for hours. It smelled like graham crackers a little, but sharper. It smelled good in the room I had sprayed it in, but to wear on me as a perfume it was too overwhelming, like a lot of Lush perfumes are.

It starts with intense citrus, it takes a moment to really feel the almond and vanilla. When the citrus dissipates it becomes sweet and comforting, pleasant, but then the almond is a bit play-dough. I thought it was good in the first 30mins or so of wearing it, but it became too much, too artificial, and a bit cheap imo. Its not terrible but there are better sweet vanillas out there.

I really don’t like this. On me it’s just way too heavy on the citrus. I was expecting something softer and creamier but it just doesn’t work for me at all.

My colleague uses the hair primer and every time she walks past I think she smells amazing so I guess it just works better as a hair product than as a perfume for me maybe.

i'm not a gourmand lover but i love the hair primer. especially with how many different whiffs of it i get throughout a day - lemon, coconut, cinnamon, almond, milk, the sweetness of a biscuit... it's all over the place in a good way. this body spray is much more linear, it is a straightforward vanilla lemon. the first spray of it is overwhelming, like melted lemon candy, but once it sits for like 10 mins it's great. still a pretty sharp lemon scent, but i love citrus so i'm fine with it. smells so good layered with Karma.

In the opening, it is very similar to the primer, but as it dries down, all I get is vanilla and almond. It's a very smooth vanilla, very creamy like nut milks, but to my nose, it's lacking some citrus and the warmth and spice of the primer on the drydown. It's quite reminiscent of BBW's Vanilla Bean Noel on the skin, almost plasticky, artificial, but if you can get past that, it's really quite delightful. It's very strong on the intial spritz but dries down to sit closer to the skin, to within an arms-length.

I paired this with Avocado Co-Wash to replace that lemon note I love so much, and my younger students walked into my classroom exclaming "why do I smell cookies!!!" -- And my coworkers pass by me saying I smell sweet like candy. If that's any indication to what this smells like, I hope it helps. To me, it just smells creamy and not too warm or heavy, creamy like the hair primer consistency hehe.

(This is a review for the glitter mist spray, not the regular body mist spray! Read the last paragraph if you’re debating which version to get ) In my opinion the glitter mist spray is way closer to the original hair primer scent than the body mist spray. I first tried the super milk hair primer spray and absolutely fell in love with it. It smells like a warm, comforting, lemon sugar cookie. I’ve always loved gourmands but disliked citrus scents very much, so this took me aback with how much I adored it from the first time wearing it. I remember the first time I bought super milk, I sprayed it in my hair immediately after leaving the store. And while I was walking around the mall, I had 3 people come up to me and ask me what fragrance I was wearing because it smelled “heavenly.” One of the people who asked me literally ran up to me, they were sniffing me down around the mall and rushing to find me before I left so I could tell them what I had on. With all lush scents, it’s very strong and long lasting. I truly don’t mind paying around the $45 price point for lush body mists because they last longer than some perfume I have that cost $200.

If you are thinking about which version of super milk body mist to buy, I’d say go for the glitter. The glitter smells closest to the original, most people say the standard body mist smells way too lemony and not enough gourmand, and that you can’t smell any of the coconut milk at all. I saw someone describe it as “windex with a sugar cookie smell” lol. Not to mention, the glitter mist is more bang for your buck as well. In the USA, the glitter mist is $26 for 8.4 fl oz, and the regular mist is $45 for 6.4 fl oz. Also I personally love the glitter aspect and packaging, I don’t care at all about packaging, but glitter mist packaging is “less ugly” than standard lush packaging. Overall, glitter mist wins in every category!
It's not bad, it actually smells quite nice, but it really just smells like a sweet candle to me. Also I wish the packaging didn't look like a cleaning product.

this smells like a watered down version of the lush perfume. I get a lot of lemon halls cough drops, and just a little bit of the milky almondy sweetness in the dry down.the glitter version is much more similar to the hairspray

Like many others, I blind bought the Super Milk body mist after falling in love with the hair product. While the scents are similar, they’re not identical. The mist opens with a strong lemon note that initially reminds me of a multipurpose spray. Thankfully, it settles into a softer, lemon-meringue pie scent, somewhat like D&G Devotion, but it's still lacking that lovely biscuity note. It’s pleasant enough and I’ve had a few compliments, but it doesn’t have the same wow factor as the original hair product -disappointing given the price.

I’ve been wanting to try the body spray and original hair primer for some time, so I ordered both along with a Supermilk body butter and a lotion and body wash of Superfairy. The hair primer smells really good like sweet milk as well as the body butter, but the spray is named wrong. This is a creamy lemon meringue that reminds me of Lattafa Victoria a lot. It smells delicious and I love it but I feel like the body spray is false advertising and Lush missed the mark here. They should not have released a milk body spray unless it was going to smell like the original hair product.

With that said, the potency is surprising for a body spray and at least they make it worth the 40 bucks they charge! I really like this and I’m definitely going to be wearing it!



Edit 9/2: So I’m actually really loving this!! On clothing the lemon is stronger but on my skin it smells like à lemon amaretti cookie( biscuit) with a rich creaminess that is so yummy and cozy! I layered this as my bedtime scent with Super Fairy body wash and Super Fairy body lotion, Bath and Body Works Milk lotion, and Orena Fragrances Strawberry Marshmallow body oil and it smells incredible! The body spray is so strong that even with the very potent oil, the spray is the main scent dominating.

In case you’re wondering about Super Fairy, it smells like the pink amoxicillin you used to get as a kid, when you smell it in the containers, but leaves a much better smell on the skin.

I tested the hair primer first on my hand I thought it had a nice smell but quickly faded, tested out the body spray and oh my it smells like a lemon sourhead with a vanillac citrus sweetness and it has some staying power I continue getting swiffs of myself after a few hours. It was an immediate purchase upon first sniff. Might purchase the hair primer in the future to pair with it.

Tested the hair treatment.. holy smokes it smells rank I hope i never encounter anyone who uses it. Literally like pouring overly sweetened lemon essential oil all over urself o_o Had a similar experience with all their perfumes i sampled. They smell like essential oils which is to say they sit weirdly on the skin, are astringent and badly blended.

omg. absolutely lovely lemon pound cake scent, a bit creamier and vanilla heavy than avocado co wash but you can definitely smell the citrus.

if you’ve ever walked into a mall and can smell a lush that’s a whole floor away from you, that’s what this body spray is.

silage is crazy, i go noseblind to almost everything and i can smell this on myself hours later.

A diluted version of the beloved hair treatment "super milk." Doesn't have that true lemon note that I loved so much in. The almond and sugary notes come through more than a lactonic or citrus (the best parts of the hair treatment IMO). It is the closest "dupe" I've found yet. It will take some layering to find the true replica but I do quite like it.

The opening is very vanilla tea biscuit and the dry down is soooooo similar to a bag of BIG LEAGUE CHEW GUM.

Silage is great for a body spray with such subtle notes.

This paired with the hair treatment is the best. There's something about the spray alone that's not giving super milk but when the hair treatment is in, I've achieved true nirvana. Hope it sticks around.
I love it, people tell me i leave the smell in every room and it lasts a week on clothes, all day on the body, but i have the glitter version if that makes a difference.
why is everybody hating?? imo this smells great! heaaaavy on the citrus but still has the creamy-sweet element to it. def a fave from lush

This one smells great however it smells more like a body mist of chelsea morning than it smells like the super milk hair product. IMO the glitter spray version (which I also have) of this is more similar to the hair product than the body mist version.

this body spray was a complete let down, the first spray is just a blast of citrus and it dries down to something i cant quite describe but its absolutely horrible and unwearable. none of the notes listed describe what it smells like, it smells like rotten perfume. UNWEARABLE! you are better off buying chelsea morning as it is dead on for the actual supermilk hair primer.

right off the bat, i immediately notice that the body spray is missing the “burnt” milky note that makes the hair primer absolutely enticing and addicting. this is a zesty punch that reminds me of lemon hard candies with clorox, it’s giving granny. to me, this is not gourmand but a summery bright fragrance, i’m not getting any vanilla or creaminess. i also think that the glitter spray smelt more similar to the primer than this. disappointed af because i could of just bought another hair primer, but to make this a “combo” i’ll pair it with silk + noir’s marshmallow citrus whip body oil phlur tangerine boy or philosophy lemon custard body lotion for something brighter. it’s not beating the cleaning spray allegations at all

i don't know how i feel, its def missing the milky aspect. i don't know why they try to replicate the hair primer in perfumes/sprays. the true super milk smell just might be unattainable in an alcoholic fragrance format. i would say the glitter spray is the better one, as its milkier but kinda has a watery feel to it. (not that bad tho)

i got a defected one so i requested a refund so i kind don't feel as ripped off, i would say its not as needed only if youre searching for super milk. if you enjoy lemon gourmand scent profile you might not mind it as much.

First 15 minutes, it. reminds me of lemonheads in a bottle; similar to Lush's other scent "Chelsea Morning". After 20 minutes total, the vanilla came through. Took at least 30 minutes to dry down completely. I would describe this as a lemon/vanilla blend. Good mix of both. The lemon in this is like a custard. No cleaner or lemon pledge vibes here (thank god!) Lasted a good while, with overspraying, 3-4 hours.

At first, I was skeptical of buying this body spray because a ton of people said that it smelled nothing like the hair primer. I really liked the way the hair primer smelt and ended up getting a sample of it when I was getting another body spray by lush. When the body spray finally came out, I can see what people are saying about it not smelling similarly to the primer however, once you allow the body spray to dry down, it’s actually really nice and I would say maybe 70% similar. I did not like the glitter body spray. It did not last on me and I feel like it’s a distant cousin of the hair primer.

Anyways, about this body spray, it lasted very long on me. I had sprayed it on myself around 3 PM the previous day while being in my house and I still smelt it on myself the next day at night. I couldn’t smell it because it was very faint, but for some reason, my sister did when she was very close to me. When you first initially spray it, it’s very lemon-y but it does dry down into a really nice vanilla biscuit. It kind of reminds me of Jackie Ainas Hard to Get. I like it. I think if you’re skeptical, go in the store, spray it on yourself, let it marinate and come to a conclusion yourself if you like it or not.

notes/ingredients: litsea cubeba oil, tonka absolute, vanilla absolute, almond essential oil, benzyl benzoate, citral, coumarin, limonene, linalool

Super Milk starts out incredibly lemon heavy, literally straight lemon essential oil. the lemon effect lasts about 15 minutes on my skin and then the tonka, vanilla, and almond start to come out. The dry down smells like a dialed-back version of Sticky Dates (I like Sticky Dates but it is nuclear in projection, I find Super Milk to be more wearable). I'm happy to have picked this one up, but you have to be a fan of lemon to enjoy it

Got an email stating 5 new body sprays released, saw ‘Supermilk’ and rushed to Lush to try them out. Lush had recently released a Supermilk Glitterspray, but glitter is just not my thing. They also had a perfume, but sold out immediately so this body spray was music to my nose.

The scent is about 80% similar to that of the cult favorite hair primer. The similarities are in the lemon forward opening and the gourmand tonka/vanilla layer. The main difference is the almond/coconut backdrop of the spray is more prominent in the heart and drydown, giving it a fuzzy, summery sun-balm quality.
The hair primer sillage smells more like ‘candy’. Wearing both will not conflict.

When comparing to Chelsea Morning perfume, it has a very similar opening. However they diverge into two different paths. Chelsea Morning leans more buttery, toffee-esque, with a smoky incense base. Their dry downs don’t smell alike.

After hearing Supermilk body spray may be limited edition, I walked out with it. I would compute the overall scent profile to a combination of Lush’s perfume Furze (which I’ve been wanting for awhile) over top of Supermilk Hair Primer.

At $45 USD for 200ml, it’s a delectable treat for the end of summer, and an excellent value!

I probably hit the jackpot with the batch that I got because WOW, the performance is excellent. It’s very strong and long lasting, I can smell it all day and even after taking a shower before bedtime. I‘ve gotten a shit amount of compliments - everyone was asking "what‘s that unique smell???" the other day in uni. People around me are absolutely in love with this perfume, I guess it blends really well with my skin. A friend told me I smell like a mysterious witch (I‘m a 24 yo guy), another friend told me he couldn‘t imagine this scent on anyone else but me.
AND HERE‘S MY TAKE:
It smells like burning sparklers and firework on New Year‘s Eve. Very fiery, smoky, absolutely stunning
Very very unfortunately smells like armpit to me.
A big no, very pungent, notes don't go well together :( smells somewhat smoky and bitter

I usually struggle to describe perfumes beyond 'nice', 'delicate' or 'strong' but smelling this perfume actually evoked very clear & vivid visions.
After the spray, I could initially smell the smoke and almost peatiness, like in an Islay Scotch whiski. But then, after letting it sit on my skin for a while, I could start smelling the leather and then a bit later a light sweetness like incense toned down by the medicinal cloves. There is a dirty, naughty sexiness to it. Picture this, a biker wearing a leather jacket goes into a bar, drinks a whiski, then goes into a church to secretly meet their lover.
very much like Peau de Espagne from Santa Maria Novella, some people interpret it as leather others as bbq sauce
barbecue sauce upon spray, fantastic soft, slightly sweet industrial dry down
i definitely get leather jacket from this, and then someone said it smelled like bbq sauce, and now that's all i can think about

This is a very smoky leather fragrance. So smoky that it reminds me of actual bonfire. With wood and thick smoke being main notes. I appreciate Lush for their unique creations, but this one is a bit too overwhelming for me.
Some people are saying it smells smokey and like tarmac, but to me it smells like being freshly bathed on a spring day. Its very green, almost like being in a eucalypt forest.
soooooo dark & beautiful and sexy oh my god

Smells like if you put plastic tupperware in a cardboard box and accidentally left it on the stove... smoky, savoury and many different types of burnt. Not for me but definitely for a steampunk motorcyclist who blasts German techno from a portable speaker in residential areas
Just here to say there's solid versions listed of VLJ ❤️

I bought this because of the bad reviews. It turns out everything that everyone hates is what I like, and that’s fine. This is THE best perfume by Lush. I have wanted a Lush perfume for years. Always finding myself in a Lush store browsing the perfumes wanting to love them. Then I stumbled on this + the reviews sold it to me, the name does it no justice. This is quite simply an Asylum Hospital on fire and I am living for it. I have Zoologist T-Rex and it’s kinda in that realm, if you know. Thank you to all the people who gave this descriptive “bad” reviews. It’s fire, medicine, spice and all things nice.

I think I finally found something from Lush that I hate. This smells burnt and somewhat like gasoline?! I had accidentally sprayed it on my clothes when I was aiming for the testing strip and I could still smell it the morning after. It does in fact smell like a new, vegan leather jacket, but who wants to smell like this.
I absolutely loved the smell got a full size bottle then one day put it on and I had to scrub it off it makes me feel really sick and every time I think about it makes me heave

I love Lush for taking chances and being unapologetically edgy.
Why wouldn't you name 'Vegan' something that smells just like bacon?

Agree with other reviewers, top notes are STRANGE right out the bottle.
Settles down to be very orange/spicy, smells almost like cumin, I think? I was reminded of hay, that sort of dry and sweet scent. My boyfriend thought it smelt like strawberries, but I didn’t get that at all. He also thought it just smelt like a Lush store.
For me, it felt quite intense. Bit of a headache inducer, but I could not stop smelling it.
Last notes were lovely. Wish that had been the entire fragrance – the smell of warm leather as you leave a warm café and go out into the cold night. Sweet, spicy, a little menthol-y.
All in all, not a bad fragrance! Not a blind buy, but also not a divisive one either. Smells good when it settles down, so definitely trust the process. In fact, don’t smell it at all when you first put it on, wait an hour. Think that’s what gave me the headache.
Moderate sillage. Fair price. 5/10.

Has notes in common with Breath of God but is simpler and less confusing. Vetiver is strongly identifiable in both. LOVE the clove, it makes it a little goth. I had been mixing up a body spray with tons of clove EO for myself and so I have been hooked on smelling clove-y all year. On the unisex side of masculine. The person who says it layers well is correct but I am a tomboy and this is perfect for my aura all by itself. The other person who warns not to blind buy is also correct. You’re either going to love it or hate it and I can understand both but I personally am on the LOVE side.
pork ribs slathered in barbecue sauce

To me this is a more acrid version of Lush’s 4:20 in its opening. A not unpleasant but not entirely pleasant wet bonfire, or worse, wet ashtray smell. But wait, the drydown is lovely. The smokiness remains but recedes into the background and a creamy sweetness emerges.
It’s one of those typically odd Lush fragrances. I’m a big fan of Lush fragrances and this is another addition to that long list of favourite frags.
It’s not a crowd pleaser but it’s still rlly nice. The opening is a big weird but after that it rounds out. Clove leather and smoke. There’s a spicy freshness to it

I really wanted to love this but it literally smells like burnt tarmac. Like when you're walking past a bunch of workmen in the road pouring hot black tarmac out of the back of a truck whilst scratching their sweaty butt cracks. Hard pass.

at first spritz this was a smoke bomb, with a little leather underneath offering absolutely no respite (10/10 perfect, no notes) but for some reason on my skin this just kept getting sweeter and sweeter - i'm talking All Good Things levels of sweet, if you're familiar with that. The tonka and clove combined in a way that almost reads as cinnamon to my nose, or at least on my skin. Like red-hots bubblegum sweet cinnamon scent. I wasn't opposed, but I almost missed the harshness of the opening once it was gone.

I always find Lush perfumes a bit abrasive. The last time I wore one regularly was during my teenage obsession with "Karma". I bought Vegan Leather Jacket immediately after trying it because I knew it would be fantastic for layering, and it is. Alone, it would be shocking, a nose-stinging disinfectant and a damp campfire. However, I'm a fan and often get compliments when I wear it over something sweet. If you don't want a smooth leather but a punchy one this is worth a visit.

I can see how the beginning blast of campfire-like top notes can be jarring for some people. But the heart and drydown combo of this is thing is one of the most beautiful, beckoning, bracing, and heartwarming of any smoky-leathery perfume I’m aware of. In the ranks of Sycomore, Incendo, and Bel Ami, among others, in my collection. Be patient and you’ll be rewarded.
Smells like Rauchbier. Not in a good way

Like many have said, I initially turned up my nose at this scent and wrote it off. On first spray it is intense, abrasive, and a bit 'much'.

However, the amazing, nuanced drydown had me running back to the store to grab myself a bottle for home. The scent has such a unique smokiness and heft to it that I can't help but love it. My partner, despite their opposing tastes, loves it on me as well.

This is a very odd and divisive perfume and sort of shocked me in the store. It smells like a campfire and that is it, nothing else. I can imagine it working well with layering though. Maybe with something as a contrast such as a gourmand or sweet or something clean smelling.
I didn't get around to smelling the drydown and so that may be more wearable.
If you want something similar that has already been layered and so automatically more wearable, I can recommend Ameer Al Oudh Intense.
This smells like a bbq sauce oh my god…
Those disappointed with the spray version ought to try the solid, it's been treating me a lot better and comes off quite a bit more nuanced?

Speaking of smoky scents — who knew a perfume from modern Lush with such a stupid name would actually be amazing? Back in their day, Lush’s Gorilla Perfume label put out some truly amazing heavy hitters. But over the last ten years, it’s seemed as if they’ve eschewed niche experimentalism in favor of remaking three of their popular shower gel scents over and over again in different forms. I see cause for hope in the new line of perfumes they released this year. Some, like The Dew on Their Hems, were standard niche fare, a pretty aquatic reminiscent of something you might find at Jo Malone. Others, like the fun Leonard Cohen sendup No Way To Say Goodbye, were interestingly hyper-saccharine to the point of obscurity. I can quite easily imagine this perfume, which smells somewhere between children’s toothpaste and nightcore bath bomb blackcurrant, fitting in mixed with ironic cigarette smoke on some disaffected twenty-something girl’s jean jacket. The clear standout from the collection, however, was Vegan Leather Jacket, which perhaps is trying to appeal to a tongue-in-cheek sense of postured edginess. I honestly don’t care, because this smells reminiscent of something Jorum Studios would make, and can be bought at a strip mall. There is no leather, here, only a heavy-handed trio of cloves, cade oil, and vetiver. Tart, supple, and gorgeously smoky, this opens with a blast of animalics, not unlike Monolith, and then settles into a flaming spice medley that lasts on skin for a neat couple of hours. People online seem to compare it to Estée Lauder’s creamy ‘70s spicebomb Cinnabar, but I only really agree inasmuch as the drydown occasionally drifts toward dark orange Opium territory. To me, this is really just a fine one-trick pony to scratch the arsonists itch in your wretched little heart without breaking the bank. I love to see mainstream perfume retailers cater to niche markets like this — and know that in their refusal to pander down to a younger consumer base, they will eventually be rewarded.

Tried this in the shop and after coughing, spluttering and the odd sneeze I left and decided Lush stuff wasn't for me.
An hour later I returned to buy it!
Spray, let it settle, give it 20 minutes to warm up and it's gorgeous.

Absolute bargain. Big smoky leather to start with, but it soon starts to melt into a lovely slightly sweetly spiced tobacco and clove scent

Bargain

vetiver-forward in a way that i would usually find objectionable but i'm actually obsessed with this because at first spray, it smells exactly like burnt weed resin from the bowl of a dirty bong in the best way possible. it also smells like mushrooms not in a mossy forest sense but rather in a dusty, savory sense.

the tobacco and spice notes are much more palpable in the solid form than the liquid fragrance. get the liquid if you want to smell like a leatherdyke stoner; get the solid if you want to smell like a clove cigarette hand-rolled by aforementioned leatherdyke stoner.

Hated it when I smelled it in the store. Adored it when, after I came home, I smelled the little bit of it I accidentally got on my wrist. It's an interesting scent. Heavy on the leather and wood and smoke. Almost a little plastic-y or like gasoline or burned rubber at first spritz. I love how it dries down into bonfire, though. The plastic quality changes into something muskier. It becomes both more subtle and more intricate the longer it is on the skin. A very sexy scent.

The smell of a slutty cowboy.

Ashy tobacco, peaty vetiver, and spicy clove all come together to form this really dirty, slightly animalic leather accord. After this dramatic opening, the leather accord sticks around but calms down for the ashy & smoky tobacco and earthy & woody vetiver to shine through, slight pops of clove fueled spice gives a nice nuance to the fragrance.

One of the dirtiest, mud and sweat covered, thick, and spiciest leather fragrances on the market right now. The opening is bombastic and in your face, but the dry down is much better put together because the vetiver and tobacco really tone down the possibly annoying or unpleasant animalic facets of the leather. A good introduction to animalic leathers, but I think there are better ones out there.

Very good performance and projection of 10 hours with strong projection for the first 4ish hours.

6.5/10.

Song vibe - Too Old to Die Young by Brother Dege

TLDR - Smoky, mud covered, spicy and slightly animalic leather accord that breaks down into the ingredients that make it what it is: vetiver, tobacco, and clove. Would be a good scent for a dive bar or a honky tonk.


Side note - I can sort of get the comparisons to Firewater by Jorum Studios, but I think this uses the smoky, earthy, and dark notes to form a loose leather accord more so than leaning into the smoke filled birch direction that Firewater goes into. Additionally, it’s missing that iconic citric, green, and marine nuances that Firewater has. The comparisons for when smelled in the air are still definitely valid, but when put side by side and smelled up close they are much more different than similar.
Straight up leather jacket (with the sweat) and smoke. Very strong.

I don’t have a problem with this fragrance, it’s just not for me at all. Smells very masculine, it would be a safe buy for a man who’s a fan of leather-y spicy perfumes. The tobacco and leather combo with the spices smells like something from Tom Ford, without the expensive vibe to it, which might just be me gaslighting myself because of Tom Ford’s prices. I might buy this for my dad one day.
very elegant smoky and earthy scent not too far away from some unapologetic french green leather from the 50's
Kinda gross fake leather smell. Do NOT blind buy !!!!!

No one mentioned but the leather, vetiver combo really reminds me of Zoologist - TRex. Really burning, and smoky... This is a fantastic dark scent, up there with the greats of Breath of God and The Devils Nightcap.
vegan leather jacket is the pissed off protagonist who just got done traveling for weeks on foot to have a three-part series finale battle with their father, breath of god

Vegan Leather Jacket is the best new Lush scent in many moons. Starting with a blast of smoke that veers toward—without ever outright becoming—barbecue, VLJ soon settles on skin with heavy spice rising to the fore. I can understand why Youth Dew and Cinnabar appear in the “reminds me of” section above, but it doesn’t directly relate to either. Rather, it’s as if one of those clove-dominant scents has been pared down to its bare essentials, then flung into a bonfire. Intensely smoky, intensely spicy. VLJ feels rough and rustic, but quite sexy too. Somehow, it reminds me of a leather fragrance without actually smelling of leather. Perhaps that’s the point—this is VEGAN Leather Jacket, after all.

Pure love. Started with a 30 mL, but had to upgrade to the 100 mL bottle. Gorgeous!
Smells like the smoking section of a gay bar. Instantly purchased.

A friend described it as 'beef jerky smelling' but I think it smells like a leather jacket that got drenched in smoke at a campfire. I immediately layered with Lush's Fresh As at the store for extra camping fragrance (smelled really good).
So smoky and maybe a little like food (the clove?) but that makes it cuddlier if you ask me.

This is mega smoky, and reminds me of a coal fire (not a wood fire), or like recreation scent of “olden days” smell in a museum? When you first spray it. it’s SO strong. Offensively so! But in the dry down it’s like old bonfire smoke stuck to hair - warm- and is very nice. I’d buy it for the dry down.
It really reminds me of very expensive niche smoke scents, like fire water by Jorum Studio, or Graphite by Mad et Len.
Do think it leans much more masculine. Maybe a very outdoorsy woman could wear it.

I was so happy Lush finally added some new fragrances to the mix! And i was delighted to see that they are trying to stay true to their origins meaning that their perfumes tell a story wich let's face it, they had stopped telling for the last couple or years. Lush has been doing nothing but discontinue and water down their best creations, so obviously i was absolutely thrilled to discover new fragrances labeled with art that don't just smell like citrus or like another blend that stems from breath of God.

Vegan leather jacket smells exactly like the name suggests. It smells of leather worn next to a bonfire. It's not sweet at all and might lean masucline to some because of it but obviously it's entirely unisex because why should scent be gendered? Because of the lack of sweetness there are no smores roasting by this particular bonfire. There is no softness no milkyness. Just the smell of charred firewoods stuck to the collar of your favorite (vegan) leather jacket. Somewhat reminiscent of the no longer existant "the voice of reason" it is a true experience in a bottle and i am quite statisfied about it.
really hoped id like this but to me it smells like pure cooked bacon, charred /:

I bought it today in the LUSH store and I am completely obsessed. Absolutely gorgeous, smoky scent, it has a beautiful projection and dries seductively on my skin. It's deffo unisex and has that sexy incense accent in. Sublime! Yes, it smells like an ashtray at the beginning and then it's a true love!
Ashtray :/

Opening reminds me of Tom Ford Sahara Noir, very smoky, woody, not a hint of sweetness.
After dry down I get the cloves, actually reminds me of Lushs Turmeric Latte.

I love a Lush fragrance. Most Lush frags are very individual. Shade is absolutely unique. Vegan Leather Jacker isn’t. It’s very dry, has a genuine smokiness to it; I get the amber comparisons (VLJ is kinda the country bumpkin cousin of YSL Cinnabar) but it’s not leathery. I get no leather at all really. And its reach is very poor. This frag sits close to the body - two/ three good spritzes to my skin and the same again to my clothes and after 10/15 mins I cannot smell it and no one has yet to comment on it.
Do I like VLJ? Yes I do. It’s an everyday frag. More masculine I’d suggest. I’ll continue to wear it. And for the price…why not? But don’t buy this expecting a leather bomb. You’ll be disappointed.

I wanted to be rabid about this - leather is one of my favourite notes - but I don't detect it at all. To me, this is a lovechild of Breath of God and Goddess by Lush. Very smoky, ambery, and has dried down to a skin scent within an hour. It's very unisex. It may mix well with Obsession by Calvin Klein, but I think the Obsession would be doing the heavy lifting there. This was a blind buy for me (albeit 30ml, and I'm a big Lush fan) and while I don't regret it, I doubt I'll be repurchasing it.
Vegan leather ....so plastic??

I bought this yesterday. If you liked Lush’s lovely but polarising ‘Voice of Reason’ this is the closest you’ll get. Sort of similar to ‘Hellstone’ too. It’s a fireside Smokey scent. Personally, I don’t really smell leather. It’s a charred wood and smoke perfume, with some hot curry type spices up top. If you like it but think it might be a bit too much for you, try the solid as it’s more wearable and discreet. I love a scent like this for Autumn. Voice of reason was sweeter and more BBQ. This is more Indian spices. Don’t let that put you off. It’s the scent of burning leaves and autumn.

i highly rate this perfume, i love, love love it! i work at a restaurant, you'd think serving food for 6+ hours would get rid of the smell, without re-applying? nope! it lasts! such a summery, intense, sweet fruity smell. so sad it's limited, same for grape soda. i always get told i smell like a sweet, usually squashies or the kids pierce-able lid party drinks - i get that a lot as it settles

This has a sweat note in it. If it didn’t have it, it would be so much better!


Upon maturing however, this sweat note is essentially gone.
Delicious, summer candy drink. Got me complimented.
smells intensely like gummy worms and candy, wore it to work and it became nauseating. i was expecting a fresh passion fruit scent but its not and its unfortunately unwearable for me
Smells like a p*rn star martini! Passion fruit, champagne and vanilla sort of vibe :)

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content: i smelled this once in store and it was actual genuine piss. not even a hint of floral just straight PISS i had to leave the storw and wash it off of my wrist. i simply couldnt do it. i never have reactions like that to bad scents but it was just that bad. and i love lush too ):

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content: I was so hopeful of this because of the chamomile but this is a super indolic, a bit pissy jasmine scent with insane strength

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content: Smells strongly of urine to both my partner and me, I had to wash it off.

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content:
This is exactly what it's name says. I get no other florals and no citruses. It's a perfect, clean impression of both honeysuckle and chamomile. They blend beautifully while remaining distinct.
Very, very, light for Lush, this could easily be used as body spray. (It's certainly lighter than a lot of their body sprays.)

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content:
On me this smells very natural, realistic and light. For people saying the opening is giving urine, just get through the first 5 minutes and then you'll arrive at a girl next door and effortless vibe.
It has no throw unfortunately and you'd have to hug me to smell anything

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content: i cant stand the piss smell

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content:
I have a hard time finding floral perfumes that aren't heavy, sultry, and/or earthy which I dislike. This perfume is beautiful, and perfect for spring and summer. I absolutely love it!

If you're looking for a pretty and very feminine perfume without smelling synthetic this is a great one. I'm no good at describing notes, but I think it leans a bit sweet which I love too! 💐

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content:
It’s like standing in a hot and humid, green and dewy flower garden while the sun beams down on you.

Then you piss all over it.

Then the piss dries and you are left with straight chamomile for the remainder of fragrance with hints of the green stem.

One of the few fragrances I actively dislike, that piss vibe is hard to ignore, and I typically really like chamomile as a note. 2/10

I have now unintentionally and unfortunately completed the list of “fragrances that smell like things that come out of my body.”

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content:
-Seems innocuous enough at first: green, tart, fresh scent... then the chamomile hits hard.
-There's this off-putting a cat piss vibe to it. Big NOPE. (-)

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content: This is a very comfortable, soothing scent to be in. Yet its not boring. Be aware, the first few minutes bring up the cat pee edge of chamomile but this smooths down after a while, allowing for the honeysuckle / white florals to come through. Something very innocent about this scent, like a summer meadow in your childhood. Its heading to winter as I am writing this, will be lovely to revisit this scent in the spring / warmer weather.

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content: Cheery pretty Springtime floral. Prominent lavender and chamomile gives way to white florals and waxy-plasticky-fruity 'Lush' smell. The drydown smells like something from my childhood but I couldn't say what. Nice and happy.

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content:
This is really beautiful, hazy, ashy, soft green and sweet scent. Yes it’s sweet, not synthetic sweet, It’s a realistic chamomile and honeysuckle sweet, but nothing offputting. The green edge and hazy-ness balance it out. It also has a bit floral milky, some nameless wild flowers that give soft milky scent. It’s serene and very comforting to wear in summer.


Updated on June 21, 2022:
The astringent, almost clinical edge from chamomile gives a sense of cleanliness, it cuts through the heat. I’m saddened to learn that this has been discontinued.

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content: I love this scent. It was a blind buy for me and I was really anxious because it is a bit pricey, but it worked out! While I also love Demeter’s Honeysuckle, this is not it. Demeter’s is a bright, light honeysuckle. This perfume also smells like honeysuckle, but a beautiful, deep, syrupy honeysuckle, with a dash of chamomile to ground it. Would it smell ‘sickly sweet’ to some, like a commenter mentioned below, but also smell beautifully syrupy to me? Sure, why not! It all depends on what you like. For what it’s worth, my husband who does not like florals smelled this on me immediately after I sprayed it and loved it, asked me right away what it was! The longevity and sillage is not bad, people will definitely smell this as you walk by!

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content:
I requested a sample of this from the Lush UK website and they were awesome and set me a squirt of it on a card. It wasn't ...too unpleasant (at least on the card), but it is definitely WHITE FLORAL. I really didn't pick up any chamomile, which what I was hoping would be more dominant. Sweetish. But not for me. So glad I asked for a sample before I paid!

I'll stick with Lush's Black Pearl and Demeter's Chamomile Tea for my chamomile scent needs.

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content: Reminds me of an indolic honeysuckle if that makes sense and lasts long.

product_name: Dad's Garden Chamomile And Honeysuckle Lush
review_content:
This is my least favourite of the Volume 3 range.

It is a very sickly sweet floral. Screeches at me when I smell it. Not for me.

If you love Honeysuckle definitely try this! Don't let my opinion put you off.

This reminds me of Snow Fairy in the opening, but less synthetic and plasticky. Yeah, there's the synthetic banana. I do not get the unwashed note AT ALL. It smells like one of the bath bombs in Lush, but I cannot pinpoint which one. It's probably the violet giving that soapy vibe.

What a scent! This starts with a quick blast of synthetic banana - which smells exactly like those Banana Bubblegum back in the days. This banana phase lasts for about 10 minutes before transitioning to what I call the labdanum phase, which smells very much like a man's pubic area (with all the unwashed hair) but perhaps less sweaty. I think it's wonderful but certainly not for everybody.

Hello all, I have a completely full bottle but I’m not hooked on it if anyone would like a great savings with only about 10 sprays gone please DM me. Additionally, give me a few days because I’m not that religious about checking my DM‘s every day.
If you miss Ladyboy, try Surrati Violet Oud. It’s more of a green banana and soapier, but very close.

This has been rereleased as 'fantabulosa' - lush told me that they dont plan on restocking this online, but it will continue to be produced & be exclusive to the Liverpool store.

As for this perfume:

For the 1st few seconds, I get an unpleasant blast of synthetic banana, which then morphs into the smell of condoms, I also smell palmaviolet sweeties & theres a slightly stale mustiness in the background.
After about 30 min its just powdery violet & thankfully its pretty much just a skin scent.

The violet lasts quite a few hours, then theres a ghost of something ever so slightly sweet & musty, I guess kinda unwashed smelling - but it's hard to describe when I can barely smell it


I can usually find something that I can appreciate in a fragrance, even if it's not my cup of tea, but I've thought over this & made myself wear it 3 times - the only nice thing I can say is that the colour of the juice is very pretty.

Lush describe this as being "sophisticated" & "chic" - which does make me question their understanding of those words, because smelling like some manky old pick 'n' mix that's been stored in a condom, doesn't really fit my understanding of either. If you realllllllly love violet, you might be able to enjoy this - but for me, it sadly just turns my stomach
Not a review but a public announcement that Lush have brought this back under a new name: Fantabulosa. I think it might be limited edition. It is available on the website.

Smell of banana? Maybe, but only if dried banana of the pack, slippery and sticky dried banana on a background with mix of nail polish hint sweet candy's. Give odds to many of niche creations. As for me, so it's for a cool sunny autumn days! Projection is very good. My black bottle from 2011 spill at the bottom of the sticker [Made by Tracy 23/05/11] became acquainted with other flavors series, but nothing so impressed how this fragrance - LadyBoy. Limit edition, removed or in stock now? Give a sing if they bring it back! It's a huge shame to discontinued it! Hey Mark, please, bring it back! There is so many people who appreciate this perfume.

Someone on another board mentioned that LUSH is discontinuing several of their fragrances, so I rullshed to their site, and the Lady Boy liquid (is it an EDT? EDP?) is sold out. The solid perfume was available so I got that. I learned my lesson; don't wait forever to buy something you love, and I do love this one. The opening has a sense of humor with the strong banana note, but the dry down is wearable, lovely, and surprisingly sophisticated. But I really wanted it in the largest size.
***** THIS FRAGRANCE HAS BEEN DISCONTINUED - STOCK UP NOW!****

This perfume is both more and less weird than sniffing the bottle lead me to think it would be.

Just sniffing the bottle-or a tester strip-what you get is holy-crap banana. At the co-op where I buy most of our groceries they have a little hot food section, and one of the things they serve for breakfast is French toast made with a reduction of bananas and walnuts. I always scrape off the lumps of banana, but I like eating it, and Ladyboy smells powerfully of something you should serve on an egg- washed piece of sauteed baguette.

Unless and until you put it on your skin. Then it's an entirely different perfume. It's amazing, really. The banana evaporated from my skin immediately and left behind a sugar-caramelizing smell (breakfast!), which almost immediately yielded to a powerful scent of oakmoss. An hour later it smelled like leathery oakmoss-which is fine with me, since I love both leather and oakmoss-and then an hour or so later it also revealed a lovely green powdery smell.

But the crowning glory was what it did after about four or five hours: it gave me a breath of Camay soap. How weird is that? I loved my grandmother's Camay when I was a kid. Do they still even make it?

This is one of the most interesting perfumes I've ever tried. It was a real journey, and I liked every bit of it. I got all this from trying a 1 ml tester! I will probably buy an actual bottle and add it to my stable of daily wear perfumes.

What a fun fragrance!

I get banana, chocolate, violet & oak moss on my skin. This is a great scent for men as well as women. For those who like something earthy-sweet. Great for summer.

I have been sniffing my empty decant of this for about a year and am on the fence about it. Yes, it has an initial, rather cheeky, banana note at the beginning and then dries down to something, IMO, very sophisticated. I love violet and violet leaf is one of the notes; I must like oakmoss too. I'll update this review if I get it.
Banana's all the way. I don't like it.

Ladyboy hasn't grown on me as much as other fragrances from Lush have. I'm not surprised that this is a men's scent. The dark, somewhat thick oakmoss drydown is very masculine on me.

Just when I thought Lush Cocktail smelt a bit like bananas, Ladyboy comes along to show me what Lush's spin on banana really smells like. I can't say that I like the powdery, candied banana scent in Ladyboy, but I do welcome the violet and chamomile accords.

This fragrance overall is fairly musky and herbal. On a man's skin Ladyboy would smell very unique, like a breath of fresh air. The name of this fragrance may be a deterrent to some, but believe me when I say that all men, regardless of their sexuality would enjoy wearing Lush Ladyboy.

The oakmoss in the base lends a real chypre quality to this composition. I really enjoy this somewhat dry, earthy component. Ladyboy's sillage decreases towards the base, softening considerably before fading away altogether.

Ladyboy's longevity is fairly impressive, at least five hours. I'd be interested to smell this fragrance on other people's skin. I don't like the way it smells on me, but I think it has some real potential.
Someone gave me a sample of this and I'm getting simply a patchouli/vetiver mix - huh? No bananas or anything else listed above. No longevity.

Happy and colourful flamboyance!

As everyone else has said, this is definitely a unisex scent.

Personally I loved it, and after seeing another reviewer compare it with banana sweets, that is my opinion too, but in the best possible way.

I was hounded by a Lush rep when trying this in the store (as is standard in Lush...), and basically all she kept repeating was what a 'fun' fragrance it was... Maybe she got it exactly right, or her words have just mingled with the smell memory engraved on my brain, but that's exactly what I think of now when I think of LadyBoy... 'Fun'.

I don't think this is a fragrance just for men at all. It is more of a green unisex scent, not a superficial/fresh green either, but a rather deep one. The banana stays mainly in the opening, where it is overwhelming a little - and it is more like banana syrup really. But this lasts only for about a half hour, then it evolves with the rest of the notes creating this kind of "greenness" which is very sophisticated. For a Lush creation, the violet is not very noticeable, it is much better blended and balanced than what they usually tend to do with it. This is a favorite.

I know Lush are big on saving the environment... but come on! This could have benefited from a much better bottle. The plain black pot just doesn't do it any justice. Even just putting the original 'Ladyboy' logo with the banana on the front would be preferable.

Having said that, this fragrance is very powerful on first spray - in fact, I had trouble picking any individual scents out at all! (I since found out that it was supposed to be banana.) It also lasts a very long time on me; I've even smelled it a good 15 hours after applying it, even with handwashing, etc.
In fact, the longer it's on, the better it becomes. This is definitely something that smells its best after about two or three hours. It matures into a deliciously warm, slightly spicy scent with a tiny hint of mint. After that, only the violets are detectable, but they do last ages! This definitely lives up to its moniker of 'quirky,' but it's just not unisex to me. Again, I think it might be the violets; I can barely smell the oakmoss.

I've now worn Lush LADYBOY several times, a testament to the potency of this house's potions. My sample vial contained 2 ml, but it seemed as though I'd never reach the bottom! Of course, that's great news, if you happen to like the rough-hewn, home-grown "perfumes" of this house. The largest size they come in is a 1 ounce bottle--and with good reason!

My problem with Lush in general is that I find the compositions harsh, not lush. Even the ones which are less harsh are still so much more harsh than most niche perfumes. Have I become a snob?

LADYBOY opens evocatively with a blast of artificial banana which instantly calls to my mind my walks home from junior high school. Why? Because there was a Tenneco along the route, and I often stopped there to buy candy, with Beich's Bananas at the top of the list. I have no idea why I liked that candy. If I saw it today, I'm sure that I'd read the ingredient list and veto it immediately. It's bound to be filled with a laundry list of non-food items. What was great about this candy was that it came shaped in these huge rectangular pieces that filled your whole mouth, and the texture was totally awesome (and I have chosen those words deliberatively!). I'm sure that Beich's Bananas are (or were--not sure if they still exist...) every dentist's dream come true. How many fillings have need to be fixed because of Beich's Bananas? I ask most sincerely.
